Fernanda Ostrovski\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\">Institute of Astronomy, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK</div><div class=\"aff\">Kavli Institute for Cosmology, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-internal\">\r\n    <a href=\"http://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=author:%22Ostrovski Fernanda%22\">Google Scholar</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-ads\">\r\n        <a             </span>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n<div class=\"pub-history-wrap clearfix\">\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row clearfix\">\r\n            <div   <li class=\"toolbar-item item-pdf\">\r\n        <a class=\"al-link pdf article-pdfLink\" data-article-id=\"4970775\" href=\"/mnras/article-pdf/479/4/5060/25716214/sty911.pdf\">\r\n            <img class=\"toolbar-item item-link item-split-view\">\r\n                                <a href=\"javascript:;\"\r\n                                   class=\"split-view js-split-view st-split-view\"\r\n class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down               <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\"       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input     <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121176957 id=\"121176957\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery, spectroscopic confirmation, and preliminary characterization of 24 gravitationally lensed quasars identified using <em>Gaia</em> observations. Candidates were selected in the Pan-STARRS footprint with quasar-like WISE colours or as photometric quasars from Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), requiring either multiple detections in <em>Gaia</em> or a single <em>Gaia</em> detection near a morphological galaxy. The Pan-STARRS <em>grizY</em> images were modelled for the most promising candidates and 60 candidate systems were followed up with the William Herschel Telescope. 13 of the lenses were discovered as <em>Gaia</em> multiples and 10 as single <em>Gaia</em> detections near galaxies. We also discover 1 lens identified through a quasar emission line in an SDSS galaxy spectrum. The lenses have median image separation 2.13 arcsec and the source redshifts range from 1.06 to 3.36. 4 systems are quadruply imaged and 20 are doubly imaged. Deep CFHT data reveal an Einstein ring in one double system. We also report 12 quasar pairs, 10 of which have components at the same redshift and require further follow-up to rule out the lensing hypothesis. We compare the properties of these lenses and other known lenses recovered by our search method to a complete sample of simulated lenses to show the lenses we are missing are mainly those with small separations and higher source redshifts. The initial <em>Gaia</em> data release only catalogues all images of \u223c30\u2009per\u2009cent of known bright lensed quasars, however the improved completeness of <em>Gaia</em> data release 2 will help find all bright lensed quasars on the sky.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: observational&quot;\">methods: observational</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: general&quot;\">quasars: general</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121176959 id=\"121176959\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">There are currently fewer than 40 known gravitationally lensed quasars with image separations over 2 arcsec. The multiple images of these bright wider-separation systems can be monitored to determine time delays, which are used to calculate a time delay distance and hence infer the Hubble constant (Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1966</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). This is a promising method to shed light on the apparent tension between local distance measurements (Riess et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and CMB measurements (Planck Collaboration XIII <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Lensed quasars are also powerful tools to probe the many facets of galaxy evolution: lens mass distributions (Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Mediavilla et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), source quasar accretion discs (Rauch &amp; Blandford <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Pooley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), source quasar host galaxies (Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Bayliss et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Ding et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), etc. However the results of all these studies are currently hindered by the dearth of known lensed quasars.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The first Pan-STARRS data release (Chambers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) has provided arcsecond-resolution, multiwavelength (<em>grizY</em>) imaging of three-quarters of the sky. This provides the perfect data set to increase the number of bright lensed quasars through area alone. Furthermore the multiwavelength data allow characterization and pre-selection of the most promising candidates to spectroscopically follow up through the use of residual features, goodness of fit, and SED similarity. While many techniques exist for identifying lenses from purely photometric data (Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), all are plagued by contaminant systems that resemble lensed quasars. These include compact star-forming galaxy pairs, binary quasars, and quasars projected close to blue stars and galaxies. Additionally, the resolution of ground-based imaging data often blends the separate components of lensed quasars into just one catalogued object. This blending by the point spread function (PSF) on the scale of the image separation leads to contaminant systems being confused for lensed quasars. One way to overcome this blending issue is to use the excellent resolution of <em>Gaia</em> (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), which is able to separate two point sources separated by \u223c0.1 arcsec (Fabricius et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Only a catalogue of detections is currently released from the <em>Gaia</em> collaboration (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>), however this is enough to quickly reduce the number of contaminants. Even though <em>Gaia</em> has not catalogued all components of close pairs (Arenou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), the knowledge that a point source exists in a system removes some star-forming galaxy contaminants from the search.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The selection, follow-up, and modelling of lensed quasars using Pan-STARRS and <em>Gaia</em> data form the basis of this paper. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> we describe the search techniques and the starting photometric quasar catalogues. Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> explains the observations and their outcomes, and in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a> we create light profile and mass models for the systems. Finally we discuss the individual systems and summarize our findings in Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) magnitudes are quoted in the AB system. The conversions from Vega to AB for ALLWISE data are <em>W</em>1<sub>AB</sub> = <em>W</em>1<sub>Vega</sub> + 2.699 and <em>W</em>2<sub>AB</sub> = <em>W</em>2<sub>Vega</sub> + 3.339, which are given in Jarrett et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and in the ALLWISE explanatory supplement. When required, a flat cosmology with \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> was used.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121176963 id=\"121176963\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 LENS CANDIDATE SELECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The following section describes the candidate selection process. The declination range was limited to \u2273\u00a0\u2212\u00a030, i.e. requiring <em>grizY</em> imaging from Pan-STARRS. For the majority of searches we required the systems to have a galactic latitude, |<em>b</em>|\u00a0&gt;\u00a015, however in some right ascension ranges (RA \u223c 80, along the galactic anticentre) this was relaxed. Before a final sample was established, the local <em>Gaia</em> stellar density for each candidate was required to be less than 50\u00a0000 stars per square degree (calculated by counting <em>Gaia</em> sources within a 100 arcsec radius), in order to remove star clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two quasar candidate catalogues are created, and two <em>Gaia</em>-based selection methods are applied to these catalogues to generate our final sample, as described in the following subsections.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121176966 id=\"121176966\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Photometric quasar candidate catalogues</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121176967 id=\"121176967\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-1>2.1.1 I. WISE mid-infrared colours</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Stern et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) have shown that the W1 and W2 bands of WISE (Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) can be used to select AGN by applying the colour criterion of W1\u2212W2 \u2265 0.16 (AB). One advantage of this selection technique is its simplicity and effectiveness (Wu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), however a downside for our purposes is that lensed quasar photometry can be strongly affected by the lensing galaxy, leading to WISE colours bluer than those of isolated quasars.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To overcome this, we apply a looser WISE criterion of W1\u2212W2 \u2265 \u22120.14. With this limit we do not expect an unreasonable number of contaminants still meeting our <em>Gaia</em> detection criteria of Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>. The main contaminant created by this lower limit is quasar+star projections.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We ensure that the WISE detections are robust in W1 and W2 by requiring catalogue uncertainties and a W1 value brighter than 18.2. After matching to Pan-STARRS and keeping objects with <em>i</em>-band PSF magnitudes brighter than 21, our initial WISE-selected quasar candidate list has 1298\u00a0877 objects with |<em>b</em>|\u00a0&gt;\u00a015.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121176971 id=\"121176971\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-2>2.1.2 II. SDSS GMM photometric quasars</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Recent papers (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Ostrovski in preparation) have shown that the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) imaging data still contain bright lensed quasars, which had not been targetted for spectroscopy and hence were missed by the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the SDSS imaging data set includes <em>u</em>-band data \u2013 which are particularly useful for selecting AGN \u2013 we create a complementary catalogue to the WISE selection above by applying Gaussian mixture modelling (GMM) classification to SDSS objects as in Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This is a morphology-independent selection based on <em>u</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>g, g</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>i</em>, and <em>i</em> \u2212W1 colours. Classification is divided into four classes: stars, galaxies, and low- and high-redshift quasars (<em>z</em> \u2272 2.7 and <em>z</em> \u2273 2.7, respectively). This classification is applied to all SDSS objects with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$psfMag\\_i\\lt 21$|\u2060</span>. Our final GMM quasar candidate catalogue is composed of all objects that have a combined (low and high redshift) quasar probability\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.5. This results in 1158557 quasar candidates.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121176974 id=\"121176974\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Morphology selection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Once a set of photometric quasar candidates is selected, we attempt to remove the objects that are not lensed quasars \u2013 mainly isolated quasars or misclassified star-forming galaxies. To this end we use <em>Gaia</em> data, which have a spatial resolution of \u223c0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>1 (Fabricius et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). <em>Gaia</em> is built to detect stars in our galaxy, but naturally detects bright quasars as a by-product. Therefore we search our quasar candidate catalogues for objects in which multiple <em>Gaia</em> sources are detected, as would be expected for multiple-imaged quasars. While this does not remove quasar+star projections from our candidates, it removes many star-forming galaxies and isolated quasars, since at most one <em>Gaia</em> detection is expected for these contaminants.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since <em>Gaia</em> does not reliably detect all images of most lensed quasars, we also describe a simple morphology selection using just one <em>Gaia</em> detection (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). While this selection naturally removes fewer contaminants, it is able to recover 45 known lenses. The details of the two methods are described below. They are both applied to each of the quasar catalogues described in\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>; Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the number of candidates each technique and quasar catalogue produced, given the selection criteria. Note that the numbers are not exclusive.</p>                        <a id=\"121176977\" scrollto-destination=\"121176977\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><em>WISE quasars (W1\u2212W2&gt;<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-$|</span>0.14)</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>1298\u00a0877<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td colspan=\"2\">MULTIPLES\u00a0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> matches\u00a0&lt;\u00a02 arcsec\u00a0</td><td>416\u00a0990\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> matches within 4 arcsec of each other\u00a0</td><td>9125\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> astrometric excess noise (AEN)\u00a0&lt;\u00a010 mas\u00a0</td><td>8889\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Stellar density\u00a0&lt;\u00a050\u00a0000 per sq. deg\u00a0</td><td><strong>8447</strong>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"2\">SINGLES\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> matches &lt;4 arcsec\u00a0</td><td>428\u00a0559\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> singles with <em>r</em><sub>PSF</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>r</em><sub>KRON</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>120\u00a0817\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> AEN\u00a0&lt;\u00a010 mas\u00a0</td><td>80\u00a0595\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Stellar density\u00a0&lt;\u00a050\u00a0000 per sq. deg\u00a0</td><td><strong>80\u00a0206</strong>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>SDSS GMM quasars</em>\u00a0</td><td>1158\u00a0557\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"2\">MULTIPLES\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> matches\u00a0&lt;\u00a02 arcsec\u00a0</td><td>686\u00a0311\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> matches within 4 arcsec of each other\u00a0</td><td>24\u00a0851\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> AEN\u00a0&lt;\u00a010 mas\u00a0</td><td>24\u00a0765\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Stellar density\u00a0&lt;\u00a050\u00a0000 per sq. deg\u00a0</td><td><strong>24\u00a0749</strong>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"2\">SINGLES\u00a0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> matches\u00a0&lt;\u00a04 arcsec\u00a0</td><td>710\u00a0052\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> singles with <em>r</em><sub>PSF</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>r</em><sub>KRON</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>54\u00a0352\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> AEN\u00a0&lt;\u00a010 mas\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0491\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Stellar density\u00a0&lt;\u00a050\u00a0000 per sq. deg\u00a0</td><td><strong>50\u00a0488</strong>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121176977\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121176978 id=\"121176978\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-1>2.2.1 Multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our first selection technique is to find quasar candidates with multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections. We require at least two <em>Gaia</em> detections within 4 arcsec of each other. Lensed quasars with separations above this are very rare (e.g. Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and the number of contaminant systems increases roughly proportionally to the maximum image separation allowed in a search. Furthermore <em>Gaia</em> is most useful at combating the blending of smaller-separation systems in ground-based optical survey data, in which lenses with images separated by more than 4 arcsec should already be deblended. This technique is applied in a two-step process: first all quasar candidates are matched to <em>Gaia</em> within 2 arcsec of the Pan-STARRS detection and secondly this is matched to <em>Gaia</em> again within 4 arcsec of the initial <em>Gaia</em> position. We choose the first matching distance to be only 2 arcsec since this retains all known lenses with two <em>Gaia</em> detections while removing some single quasar candidates projected near stars with <em>Gaia</em> detections.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121176980 id=\"121176980\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-2>2.2.2 <em>Gaia</em> detection near morphological galaxy</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Cross-matching <em>Gaia</em> to known lensed quasars (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) demonstrates that only one in five small-separation lensed quasars have all quasar images detected by <em>Gaia</em>, even when all images should be detected. Although this fraction increases with separation (one-third at the largest separations; Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), requiring multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections will miss the majority of lenses. One way to find some of these 'missing' lenses is to perform a search depending on only one <em>Gaia</em> detection. We do this but require a morphological galaxy within 4 arcsec of the quasar candidate, removing contamination from wider-separation star+quasar projections. If the single <em>Gaia</em> detection is indeed a quasar, a bright galaxy within 4 arcsec is a strong candidate for acting as a foreground lens. We crossmatch our quasar candidates to <em>Gaia</em> within 4 arcsec and then back to Pan-STARRS within 4 arcsec of our original quasar candidate but requiring the criterion of <em>r<sub>PSF</sub></em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>r<sub>KRON</sub></em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.2 for the new match. This extended object can be the original quasar candidate.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121176982 id=\"121176982\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Final lens candidate catalogue</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">After applying the <em>Gaia</em> multiple and single detection techniques to the two quasar candidate catalogues, we apply two further filters. The first is requiring the astrometric excess noise (AEN; Lindegren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) for each <em>Gaia</em> detection to be less than 10 mas. The AEN is a useful indicator for point source/galaxy separation (Belokurov et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Koposov, Belokurov &amp; Torrealba <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) which holds for known lensed quasars (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Therefore we can remove many star-forming galaxies from our search by applying the simple cut AEN&lt;10 mas. The second filter is removing all candidates with local <em>Gaia</em> stellar densities above 50\u2002000 stars per square degree. This is calculated by counting all <em>Gaia</em> detections within 100 arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The catalogues are then stacked and duplicates from the two quasar candidate selection techniques are removed, leaving 109\u00a0941 <em>Gaia</em> singles and 31\u00a0486 <em>Gaia</em> pairs. After selecting \u223c200 of the most promising candidates through visual inspection, the Pan-STARRS <em>grizY</em> images are modelled simultaneously as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>. This is to ensure the postulated quasar images have similar colours and to prioritize systems with residual features consistent with a lensing galaxy.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121176985 id=\"121176985\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectra of 60 candidates were taken with the Intermediate dispersion Spectrograph and Imaging System (ISIS) on the 4.2-m William Herschel Telescope (WHT) on the nights of 2017 March 31, April 1, September 12 and 13 . Since we only needed to identify broad emission line features, we used the low-resolution gratings, R158 (121 \u00c5 mm<sup>\u22121</sup>/1.81 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>) for the red arm and B300 (64 \u00c5 mm<sup>\u22121</sup>/0.86 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>) for the blue arm. Each lens candidate was positioned along a 1-arcsec-wide slit to capture both quasar images. Multiple position angles were used for one quad candidate, J1721+8842.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After masking cosmic rays and subtracting the sky background, the spectra were visually inspected for broad emission lines in the separated peaks and 1-D spectra were extracted using Gaussian apertures with 0.5 arcsec width.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121176988 id=\"121176988\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Results</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> shows a summary of the observations with sky positions, candidate selection method, outcome of the observation, and WISE and <em>Gaia</em> magnitudes.</p>                        <a id=\"121176990\" scrollto-destination=\"121176990\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of observations. NIQ=nearly identical quasar, assigned to systems of quasars at the same redshift but without photometric detection of a lensing galaxy. Selection shows the quasar catalogue and <em>Gaia</em> technique with which the candidate was selected: S=single, D=double, T=triple. All dates are in 2017. WISE magnitudes and colours are given in the AB system.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Selection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>W</em>1\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>W</em>2, <em>W</em>1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>Gaia</em> G<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Date, Exp. 600s\u00a0</td><td>quasar+star\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121176990\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have classified 24 objects as lensed quasars since the spectra reveal the presence of (at least) two quasars at the same redshift and the pixel modelling of the Pan-STARRS images reveals a lensing galaxy. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows Pan-STARRS <em>gri</em> cutouts of the confirmed lens systems with <em>Gaia</em> detections overlaid. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> shows the component spectra for each lens. We are able to establish the lens galaxy redshift for four lenses.</p>                        <a id=\"121176992\" scrollto-destination=\"121176992\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=t2b8Nn-jrxPKFUwH5Kb-g5-Th-WOjkhVxACI69qcn4RuVvpz31dJp9DbkUvtuTMn-5AqDC6YOwRsOq2FLlmZxfoN~PebFLKfMNEeWlQay5v9BUtWncV7T2WSJjkXKYHmb5x1XB1~vtXHyv0tqx--TDxbJltE0Z5rnoXeDnel4sf6dLcyt1SIl3qpymG6VSEtcH8OlhkE3bTJ4Zf-HKD-GUmfau-wB6e5WH~GXN5R8frqoqbSREWHTnTF85mvP7Q9mfCuF5smR1ZtrBBBMNTZq4xiOCwB7LotqFLIUpKFK5sFVvripbRx9yeqJU2XOi6xaok1Cq9MIkQdrsQ-s0p2Rw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS gri colour images of the confirmed lenses with Gaia detections overlaid with red crosses. Quasar emission lines are labelled in blue, and lens galaxy absorption lines in green where identified.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We further discover 10 systems consisting of pairs of quasars at the same redshift, shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. Their spectra are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. However in these systems, the residuals after PSF subtraction do not convincingly demonstrate a lens, or the spectral features rule out the lensing hypothesis. See Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a> for details on individual systems. Summaries of key characteristics of lensed quasars and nearly identical quasars are shown in Tables <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"121176995\" scrollto-destination=\"121176995\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=lOUFPGVGnmT96Afimd3AesNEjO3BpYvmlvAotuxyIKokDE--KpVwdTLKXWJmVv9B7d27z41VXdgnbV1b8eXQIOiNBRCXCgdc-SYmj~TE-lKmbJzWpYyl7uUzb--WDC73CB8PEQ5bV0w0o~s9YeG~GismHbTQDQJy2cA2kmBDCM8IiXvEPEyLdqwkuC8CkaFouAnpqGHWDLalAHJjTxuTKrkv0zE7PIzn8mop4NyiQqGtNReEmOJATWshK64Wu073rNSYK0zN25z19POD27h8H8OMAfaK1bdSxL~eJ4pwffnvQRlyD8~jYvqZZ~~LXpqbPjV6UAJRD44D67~ygEWsrg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS gri colour images of the nearly identical quasars. (\u2033)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>i</em><sub>mag</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J0127\u22121441\u00a0</td><td>1.76\u00a0</td><td>2.96\u00a0</td><td>19.30\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0139+3526\u00a0</td><td>0.65\u00a0</td><td>2.22\u00a0</td><td>18.49\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0140+4107\u00a0</td><td>2.50\u00a0</td><td>1.44\u00a0</td><td>16.94\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0740+2926\u00a0</td><td>0.98\u00a0</td><td>2.59\u00a0</td><td>18.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0812+3349\u00a0</td><td>1.49\u00a0</td><td>1.99\u00a0</td><td>19.12\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1139+4143\u00a0</td><td>2.23\u00a0</td><td>2.30\u00a0</td><td>18.86\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1540+4445\u00a0</td><td>0.61\u00a0</td><td>2.74\u00a0</td><td>19.21\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1821+6005\u00a0</td><td>2.05\u00a0</td><td>1.48\u00a0</td><td>19.34\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2032\u22122358\u00a0</td><td>1.64\u00a0</td><td>1.91\u00a0</td><td>18.40\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2057+0217\u00a0</td><td>1.52\u00a0</td><td>1.06\u00a0</td><td>18.96\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121176998\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121176999 id=\"121176999\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 MODELLING</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121177000 id=\"121177000\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Pixel modelling</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section we model the Pan-STARRS <em>grizY</em> imaging data for each lens system to derive simple component shapes, positions, and colours. In the next section we use the image and galaxy positions and flux measurements to fit simple lens models to each system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The PSF is derived by fitting a Moffat profile (Moffat <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1969</a>) to a nearby star. The <em>grizY</em> Pan-STARRS images are modelled simultaneously with each quasar image fit with a PSF, and galaxies fit with S\u00e9rsic profiles (S\u00e9rsic <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1963</a>) convolved with the PSF. In all lens systems, the presence of a lens galaxy is apparent from the colour image, except for J0630-1201 and J1606-2333. The free parameters for the pixel modelling are the positions of the quasar images and the lensing galaxy, as well as the flattening, size, and S\u00e9rsic index of the galaxy, all of which we assume to be the same across bands. The log likelihood is sampled using the <span class=\"small-caps\">emcee</span> package Foreman-Mackey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) to determine statistical uncertainties. Finally the fitting is repeated with a different PSF star to determine the systematic error for a possible PSF mismatch.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> shows the Pan-STARRS <em>gri</em> images and the residuals after modelling each system as the relevant sum of quasars and galaxies. Astrometry and photometry for all available bands are given in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1a\" data-open=\"tbl1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"121177004\" scrollto-destination=\"121177004\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=uLx1A7vHnf2LdcwoWOeQWar~CQ-uVNKsnF6ipntzQoDrjQq9zQD5BksAb-xPRZ5jpfR0WS8bWoPEI3x0VYb8H3FRex4v7fpG3VXsNHId9sl9TUsNdg3A9LdP6uyPBsKJ8vDdT2Hnsx8fHU~1LNx354BZpxqMIKVqo4sgMTJLlm-7t9OkHN~m6ap1R-Ls8WMjCxn~SF5Rf4CRCcKMkA~~UnTL5v8C5q8UvQvirg0l4uMhiaGl8I2xZuXVBmEz08xh8u5nFyMIFLKizoqW6QChKxaJ~OO-I2LeNYF9A7QVsBaAqFYdtbeuCO8F~oWDRc5LNJOsDGU3Ijm8tkp55tLQJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pixel modelling of the confirmed lenses. Left to right: gri data, model, gri PSF-subtracted, and r-band residuals. Blue crosses indicate the positions of quasar images and red plusses mark the locations of lensing galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177004/sty911fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177004\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&Signature=nEuU6r8nwm~HQEZjbASoDFkBrqAR9KWA2VE9Yf5bZbaXr5~s6vrJjBqNNyKZ5v5bRUbPt~tOxxZmKVjuvNlTvynYRtq2l07x-ARkudsGdDuMdhrOiTUSAwscZKQ7TdcCkQ5EzcVAotygFEX68sK-SLcK0zMR1CdV71gAOYdK~hSnW8AmT4~~s16JVPWReICFEE6Y5KrEsmm57hviKOI2jDxvcq91gxXt5ub9A6Z-hG1M6th~7GbBS3vN3ZMsf5XXft0SOX36kOhxE1gq7r0V-i1ItuU2F1dumO8s1yWlbmF9kYH07WkM4eKnjbBGEcX63M32TshR3DiT-aZNAIB0bg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177004&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pixel modelling of the confirmed lenses. Left to right: <em>gri</em> data, model, <em>gri</em> PSF-subtracted, and <em>r</em>-band residuals. Blue crosses indicate the positions of quasar images and red plusses mark the locations of lensing galaxies.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=uLx1A7vHnf2LdcwoWOeQWar~CQ-uVNKsnF6ipntzQoDrjQq9zQD5BksAb-xPRZ5jpfR0WS8bWoPEI3x0VYb8H3FRex4v7fpG3VXsNHId9sl9TUsNdg3A9LdP6uyPBsKJ8vDdT2Hnsx8fHU~1LNx354BZpxqMIKVqo4sgMTJLlm-7t9OkHN~m6ap1R-Ls8WMjCxn~SF5Rf4CRCcKMkA~~UnTL5v8C5q8UvQvirg0l4uMhiaGl8I2xZuXVBmEz08xh8u5nFyMIFLKizoqW6QChKxaJ~OO-I2LeNYF9A7QVsBaAqFYdtbeuCO8F~oWDRc5LNJOsDGU3Ijm8tkp55tLQJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pixel modelling of the confirmed lenses. Left to right: gri data, model, gri PSF-subtracted, and r-band residuals. Blue crosses indicate the positions of quasar images and red plusses mark the locations of lensing galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177004/sty911fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177004\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&Signature=nEuU6r8nwm~HQEZjbASoDFkBrqAR9KWA2VE9Yf5bZbaXr5~s6vrJjBqNNyKZ5v5bRUbPt~tOxxZmKVjuvNlTvynYRtq2l07x-ARkudsGdDuMdhrOiTUSAwscZKQ7TdcCkQ5EzcVAotygFEX68sK-SLcK0zMR1CdV71gAOYdK~hSnW8AmT4~~s16JVPWReICFEE6Y5KrEsmm57hviKOI2jDxvcq91gxXt5ub9A6Z-hG1M6th~7GbBS3vN3ZMsf5XXft0SOX36kOhxE1gq7r0V-i1ItuU2F1dumO8s1yWlbmF9kYH07WkM4eKnjbBGEcX63M32TshR3DiT-aZNAIB0bg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177004&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pixel modelling of the confirmed lenses. Left to right: <em>gri</em> data, model, <em>gri</em> PSF-subtracted, and <em>r</em>-band residuals. Blue crosses indicate the positions of quasar images and red plusses mark the locations of lensing galaxies.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121177005 id=\"121177005\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Mass modelling</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We fit all the systems with singular isothermal elipsoids (SIE) using our own <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span>-based image-plane modelling code, which has been checked for consistency with <em>lensmodel</em> (Keeton <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). We use the two-step process of modelling the pixels to find positions and fluxes, and then deriving a lens model. This is to ensure that if the system is not well-described by a singular isothermal ellipsoid, it does not affect the PSF subtraction. Furthermore we can quantify the chi-squared contributions fromTAB positions and flux ratios robustly. For all the doubly imaged lenses, we start from two image positions and a galaxy position (six parameters). However, to constrain a singular isothermal ellipsoid (galaxy position, mass, ellipticity, position angle and source position; seven parameters), we require one further observable. For this we use the image flux ratio. We take the median flux ratio from the <em>griz</em> bands and include a 20 per cent uncertainty on the input fluxes since optical flux ratios depend not only on the lensing geometry but also on extinction, quasar variability over the time delay, microlensing, etc. Using these pixel-based measurements and their uncertainties, the lens parameters are inferred through image-plane sampling. Given the extra information in quads, we are able to use more realistic models with more parameters. We use SIE+shear models for these systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lens model parameters (medians with 1\u03c3 limits) and chi-squared contributions are listed in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. For the three quadruply imaged lensed quasars, we include a 50 per cent uncertainty on the input fluxes for the two saddle point images in each system, in accordance with their increased susceptibility to microlensing (Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"121177008\" scrollto-destination=\"121177008\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Median parameter values with 1\u03c3 uncertainties for mass models and light profiles. b=Einstein radius, PA= position angle (north of west), q = axis ratio, \u03bc = total source magnification. <sup><em>a</em></sup>The mass model and galaxy light profile for J0030-1525 are based on better seeing VST-ATLAS data (Shanks et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>PA</em><sub>light</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c7<sup>2</sup><sub>flux</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03bc<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: no-formula-id\">|$4.5_{4.3}^{4.9}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121177008\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Systems with significantly elliptical SIE fits and a large image-position chi-squared are indicative of a strong external shear if the lens is not elliptical in the photometry.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121177010 id=\"121177010\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121177011 id=\"121177011\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Notes on individual systems</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177012 id=\"121177012\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-1>5.1.1 J0030\u22121525</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The Pan-STARRS <em>gri</em> image for this object shows two bright PSFs and a galaxy significantly offset from where it should lie to create a double-image system. However, a better seeing VST <em>i</em>-band image (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>) resolves four objects including a faint blue PSF next to an extended red object. This is consistent with a flux-ratio anomaly fold-configuration quad with the faint PSF being the counterimage. We model the Pan-STARRS data for photometry of A+B, C, and D+G, given in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1a\" data-open=\"tbl1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>. However, for the mass model we use the VST <em>r</em>-band data given its excellent seeing and resolution of the counterimage. The PSF is inferred from the data due to the lack of a nearby star. We find that the data are fit by models with the merging pair consisting of a bright image north-west of a faint image or vice versa. The former is much more plausible, given that saddle points are more commonly demagnified than maxima and minima (Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) and so this is the mass model we report in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. The best fit mass model gives flux ratios of \u223c7:7:3:1 while the measured flux ratios are \u223c7:0.5:4:1, i.e. a 14\u00d7 decrease for image B.</p>                        <a id=\"121177014\" scrollto-destination=\"121177014\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=1F8ZPrBciVZT2ZDeEnEWyioWQDue7jbIF1MWyffmu9Hw6McDi25sVpk8W3~YY9PR~oHf5ny~ilxHD3APbJufxYdLqDwRrSAoJ9AnwUiQcnmB7xfjs-~PSPyDd8K45T8GHPeiv6StlY19s2pG4HIGosn0ZcA6Gpwg5a6u8X9eluFNvJTCMa2GCrRVZ0hEdaCsfazM71RlNmN3g6arAAv3mQ-d~mv9bunM6bZfUA0ToLcit3BSrZWUppFkCwvns1tPpk1azB-s4AoKLtgpMmQcT2ACJxXOZY360ePQaYRiwJlVrISyHKmL0UIuhK6Wdd4zr7Hp7WpnYf-c~eaukKCR4Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"From the left: PSJ0030-1525 VST grz colour image; 0.42-arcsec-seeing r-band VST image; 4PSFs+galaxy model with PSF positions overlaid; residuals after model subtraction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177014/sty911fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177014\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&Signature=BpqJwZFH8eQTN5BmqrSBg~lNOXrMW5ZKXPrKSjeoCtKb6xepUxv4x6FiSIm71y9sPYnYRX3~s2uJxmTJy1VkV5~4CCpDIoRALmeONjnmW5wgUhd5UnycoIsFHZsf1jpI6odhrQiaw3cJx4AVK386tNK5~mdSOizbBImJNNlRRJt7gCHOrrG~NTrjTRvq2AbUT2Ur9xSbuyL060~RC7stELC0JxxwHqcuxeVN2N84vQ-Vwx4PLc3UyGfZTuyDgu9BjOcGNDVgzJT98UsVQknO0O5Z8ZRnEpfbMwE5uHAprTNWkbSQEejUVNgWx0TE1pABpfX6GzocM0rTjbFHU4Jx3Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177014&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">From the left: PSJ0030-1525 VST <em>grz</em> colour image; 0.42-arcsec-seeing <em>r</em>-band VST image; 4PSFs+galaxy model with PSF positions overlaid; residuals after model subtraction.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=1F8ZPrBciVZT2ZDeEnEWyioWQDue7jbIF1MWyffmu9Hw6McDi25sVpk8W3~YY9PR~oHf5ny~ilxHD3APbJufxYdLqDwRrSAoJ9AnwUiQcnmB7xfjs-~PSPyDd8K45T8GHPeiv6StlY19s2pG4HIGosn0ZcA6Gpwg5a6u8X9eluFNvJTCMa2GCrRVZ0hEdaCsfazM71RlNmN3g6arAAv3mQ-d~mv9bunM6bZfUA0ToLcit3BSrZWUppFkCwvns1tPpk1azB-s4AoKLtgpMmQcT2ACJxXOZY360ePQaYRiwJlVrISyHKmL0UIuhK6Wdd4zr7Hp7WpnYf-c~eaukKCR4Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"From the left: PSJ0030-1525 VST grz colour image; 0.42-arcsec-seeing r-band VST image; 4PSFs+galaxy model with PSF positions overlaid; residuals after model subtraction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177014/sty911fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177014\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&Signature=BpqJwZFH8eQTN5BmqrSBg~lNOXrMW5ZKXPrKSjeoCtKb6xepUxv4x6FiSIm71y9sPYnYRX3~s2uJxmTJy1VkV5~4CCpDIoRALmeONjnmW5wgUhd5UnycoIsFHZsf1jpI6odhrQiaw3cJx4AVK386tNK5~mdSOizbBImJNNlRRJt7gCHOrrG~NTrjTRvq2AbUT2Ur9xSbuyL060~RC7stELC0JxxwHqcuxeVN2N84vQ-Vwx4PLc3UyGfZTuyDgu9BjOcGNDVgzJT98UsVQknO0O5Z8ZRnEpfbMwE5uHAprTNWkbSQEejUVNgWx0TE1pABpfX6GzocM0rTjbFHU4Jx3Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177014&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">From the left: PSJ0030-1525 VST <em>grz</em> colour image; 0.42-arcsec-seeing <em>r</em>-band VST image; 4PSFs+galaxy model with PSF positions overlaid; residuals after model subtraction.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177015 id=\"121177015\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-2>5.1.2 J0127\u22121441</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DECaLS data reveal two faint red objects between the two PSFs that could be responsible for the lensing. These are detected only in the <em>z</em>-band data and each has a magnitude of \u223c24. Comparing to mock lenses from Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) with similar source redshift and image separation, the faintest <em>i</em>-band lens magnitudes are \u223c22. While the multiple component nature of this putative lens complicates the comparison, the faintness and large separation suggest either a binary quasar or high-redshift group lens. Deeper data will help to secure the magnitudes of these objects.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177017 id=\"121177017\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-3>5.1.3 J0139+3526</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While this was a promising candidate given the similar SEDs and residuals consistent with a lensing galaxy, the redshift of the quasars is low (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.65) and the [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission lines are significantly different. There is no discernible redshift difference from the spectra, so this system is likely a quasar merger in which we are seeing the onset of AGN activity. The residuals are probably associated with the quasar host galaxies interacting. A nearby bright star makes this system ideal for adaptive optics follow-up.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177019 id=\"121177019\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-4>5.1.4 J0140-1152</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens has been independently identified in the VST-ATLAS survey by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>), who report a lens redshift of 0.277. It is a highly magnified (\u223c10\u00a0times) double. The elliptical mass model suggests a strong external shear, given the relatively circular light profile of the galaxy.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177021 id=\"121177021\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-5>5.1.5 J0235-2433</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) have independently selected this object as a candidate gravitational lens from the Dark Energy Survey (DES) footprint (The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). We confirm the PSFs to be quasars at a redshift of 1.44. The DES data displayed in Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) show that the image closest to the lens galaxy is brighter than the other while the opposite is true in the Pan-STARRS data. This change by approximately 1 mag within less than a few years (mean epoch for the Pan-STARRS detection is 56475, and \u223c57350 for DES; Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) is likely attributed to a microlensing event rather than quasar variability. Indeed in the <em>Gaia</em> data, the closest and furthest images have magnitudes of <em>G</em>=18.12 and <em>G</em>=18.85, respectively. Since both images are detected by <em>Gaia</em>, they will have well-sampled light curves over 5\u00a0yr. When released, these light curves will clearly distinguish a microlensing event in one image from quasar variability which would be seen in both images but separated by the time delay.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177023 id=\"121177023\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-6>5.1.6 J0417+3325</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This double has an elliptical lens galaxy (<em>q</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.48) and the SIE lens model is aligned along the same position angle but less elliptical (<em>q</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.65). It was originally detected by Colla et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1970</a>) at 408MHz with a flux of 290\u2009mJy, and subsequently at 5\u2009GHz by Davis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1971</a>) and Altschuler (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>) with detections of 60\u2009mJy and 39\u2009mJy, respectively. It is also detected in NVSS (Condon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) at 1.4\u2009GHz with a flux density of 109\u2009mJy. Archival 8\u2009GHz VLA data show two point sources in the same positions as the optical quasar point sources with a hint of a third source south of image A. There is an extended source 3 arcsec west of the system, lacking any optical detection in Pan-STARRS. The A to B flux ratio at 8\u2009GHz is 1.2, while the <em>g</em>-band ratio \u2013 the magnitudes least affected by the presence of the lens galaxy \u2013 is 2.0, a discrepancy that could be explained by a number of effects including microlensing or extinction. The presence of a radio source is promising for using resolved source structure and radio flux ratios to precisely constrain lens models.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177025 id=\"121177025\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-7>5.1.7 J0630-1201</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system was identified in a novel Pan-STARRS+WISE photometric quasar catalogue as explained in Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Keck NIRC2 data reveal two lensing galaxies and a fifth demagnified image. See Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) for a full mass model.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177027 id=\"121177027\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-8>5.1.8 J0740+2926</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This is an SDSS quasar that was subsequently found to be followed up as part of the SQLS, which also confirms this as a quasar pair at <em>z</em>=0.98 (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177029 id=\"121177029\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-9>5.1.9 J0812+3349</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While we have classified this as a nearly identical quasar (NIQ), there is support for this object being a lens since a faint red object is seen upon subtracting the PSFs. Because of the lack of any imaging data sets other than Pan-STARRS, we cannot confirm this detection since this faint residual is only seen in the <em>i</em> band at <em>i</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a023. The quasars\u2019 proximity could mean lens galaxy light is being fit or appearing due to poor PSF subtraction. Therefore deeper and/or higher-resolution imaging of this system is required.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177031 id=\"121177031\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-10>5.1.10 J0941+0518</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system and J1640+1045 were concurrently discovered by Williams et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Deep CFHT data reveals an Einstein ring of the quasar host galaxy in the <em>u, g</em>, and <em>r</em> bands, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. We calculate the velocity dispersion of our SIE model to be 365\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and compare this to the measured velocity dispersion of the galaxy from an SDSS spectrum of 313\u00b118\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. This discrepancy can be accounted for by a shallower than isothermal density profile of <em>\u03b3</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.8 (see fig.\u00a04 of Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). However, this lens is embedded within a galaxy group and so close companions would suggest a steeper profile (Dobke, King &amp; Fellhauer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Since a quasar emission line from the closer, fainter quasar image is present in the galaxy spectrum, the SDSS velocity dispersion might not be trustworthy. A deeper spectrum and deeper optical imaging of the Einstein ring will help constrain the mass model. We calculate the time delay for this system as B lagging A by \u223c270\u2009d.</p>                        <a id=\"121177033\" scrollto-destination=\"121177033\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\"
