data-section=\"121177033\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&Signature=xPnP1M34fakin6kD3o9kJJ2u7I-rovQxM0LmUFMWotY5cUMi7wO7vYjgeK13s3ZxSzlL8Glhj95gXK5ZQh~OdC8IG3OMgoYN138b5gkpA-AWiLxs0jYH06UzBslatYa6BJkcV-Wce6bCWbdBuUzhKR7SpHcMWnKlYL9gCEamiCWO7GxcvBVQay~~OZwilNXyvKK68yFQDXjxIPkcsa1W~1msJtNkaELnoD4hfM-6uOkN9Tpp4p3r6bDRSrCoBxbBOgFGdVjsZxuZkjJHtxPUfPmSj7-r-0FfTteJpKqH5p1wL5eFlpDxfH~JKzWEQxZsbVivZqc8UWzjnWoLkH5lWA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177033&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">From left to right: J0941+0518 stacked CFHT <em>ugr</em> data, PSF-subtraction, and PSF and galaxy subtraction.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177034 id=\"121177034\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-11>5.1.11 J0949+4208</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This is a radio source in NVSS and FIRST, however FIRST clearly associates it with the lensing galaxy. The lensing galaxy is likely a radio galaxy, however we cannot rule out the fainter optical image being much brighter in the radio. It was targetted for a BOSS spectrum which shows quasar emission lines at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.27 and a galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.507, in agreement with the absorption lines seen in our WHT spectrum.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177036 id=\"121177036\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-12>5.1.12 J1540+4445</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This NIQ is at low redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.61) and shows variation in the emission line profiles between the two components. Furthermore it appears to be associated with a galaxy cluster. Two BOSS spectra of galaxies in the field place them at the same redshift as the NIQ.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177038 id=\"121177038\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-13>5.1.13 J1606\u22122333</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system was identified as a <em>Gaia</em> double. Though the seeing for the WHT spectrum was poor, quasar emission lines are visible across the broad trace. The two-component decomposition is made the same distance as that between the <em>Gaia</em> detections, and a narrow uniform aperture is used for the spectral extraction. An archival, shallow <em>Chandra</em> image shows extended emission at the positions of the two <em>Gaia</em> detections and also near image C, as labelled in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Recent HST imaging (proposal 15320, PI: Treu) clearly resolves four quasar images and a lens galaxy. The mass model suggests a shear of 0.15 and an image position chi-square of \u223c10. The majority of this is attributed to a poorly fitting position of image D. The best-fit models consistently place D 0.02-0.04 arcsec more northern than the measured value. This discrepancy could be explained by an astrometric perturbation from an unresolved galaxy near image D.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177040 id=\"121177040\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-14>5.1.14 J1640+1045</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This double system appears to be a flux-ratio anomaly double with the closest image 1.5 mag brighter than the further image (0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>52 and 1<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>71 from the galaxy, respectively). While this could be explained by microlensing, the fit of an SIE is possible to explain this flux ratio but requires a highly elliptical (<em>q</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.3) mass model, while the light profile is reasonably circular (<em>q</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.9). Therefore if this flux ratio is to be explained by a mass model, it is much more likely to be due to a strong external shear in the same direction as the inferred mass position angle. A singular isothermal sphere + shear model for this system is also a good fit (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\chi^2$|</span> \u223c0.25), with a shear of 0.32 at 122 deg North of East. This position angle is well-aligned with a nearby galaxy less than 4 arcsec from the main lensing galaxy at a position angle of 133 deg North of East. Furthermore SDSS, Pan-STARRS, <em>Gaia</em>, and DECaLS data all show that this lens maintains the measured flux ratio implying this flux ratio is unchanging over 15\u00a0yr. While microlensing events cannot be ruled out, it is more likely that this apparent flux-ratio anomaly is explained by a strong external shear. Since both quasar images are detected by <em>Gaia</em>, their lightcurves will become useful data for breaking the microlensing/shear degeneracy for this system.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177042 id=\"121177042\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-15>5.1.15 J1721+8842</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The 'polar quad' shows strong signs of line-of-sight absorption systems in all four images. The Pan-STARRS imaging data have highly distorted PSFs in some bands, so the mass model is based on flux ratios measured only in the <em>r</em> band. The residuals after subtracting PSFs show flux to the west of image C, perhaps associated with a second lensing galaxy or an arc from the quasar host galaxy. Given its high declination, the position and airmass of this system are essentially unchanged year-round, providing an excellent opportunity to efficiently measure time delays without any seasonal gaps. We note that the mass model is well-fit to the data, with a <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi^2$|</span> of \u223c4.4 (the number of degrees of freedom for the quad models is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$13-9=4$|\u2060</span>). Most of the flux chi-squared contribution comes from image A being too bright. This system was also recovered by Rusu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) in a lens search using the AGN catalogue of Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177044 id=\"121177044\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-16>5.1.16 J1831+5447</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This is an NVSS radio source with a flux of 23.5\u2009mJy at 1.4\u2009GHz.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177046 id=\"121177046\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-17>5.1.17 J2032\u22122358</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MgII absorption is seen in just one of the quasar spectra, with the emission lines appearing similar. The MgII absorption system is at <em>z</em>= 1.642, consistent with the source\u2019s systemic redshift based on the C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> and C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> lines and the other quasar\u2019s MgII emission line. This could be a lens with magnesium absorption in the host quasar along the line of sight of just one image. If deeper imaging reveals a lens galaxy or a lensed host galaxy, then this system could be used to constrain the covering fraction of MgII.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121177048 id=\"121177048\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Lens statistics</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To understand the limitations of our selection method, we have compiled a list of 147 previously known lensed quasars against which we can test our selection. While we report 24 new lensed quasars in this paper, our selection criteria also selected 59 previously known lensed quasars, as described in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"121177050\" scrollto-destination=\"121177050\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia</em> selection of lenses with WISE+GMM colour techniques. Numbers shown in brackets are for lenses in the Pan-STARRS footprint. 82 lenses are selected in Pan-STARRS, 23 of which are new lenses presented in this paper and the remaining 59 are known lenses.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Known lensed quasars (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>171 (150)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>4 (4)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> detections<sup><em>a</em></sup> (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>43 (34)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1 <em>Gaia</em> detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>86 (77)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>0<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>38 (35)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Multiples selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Singles selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Known lensed quasars (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>171 (150)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>4 (4)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> detections<sup><em>a</em></sup> (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>43 (34)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1 <em>Gaia</em> detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>86 (77)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>0<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>38 (35)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Multiples selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Singles selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>One of these 43 lenses \u2013 SBS1520+530 \u2013 has one of its two detections due to a nearby star. We keep this in our sample since it would still be selected via this method.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121177050\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia</em> selection of lenses with WISE+GMM colour techniques. Numbers shown in brackets are for lenses in the Pan-STARRS footprint. 82 lenses are selected in Pan-STARRS, 23 of which are new lenses presented in this paper and the remaining 59 are known lenses.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Known lensed quasars (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>171 (150)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>4 (4)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> detections<sup><em>a</em></sup> (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>43 (34)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1 <em>Gaia</em> detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>86 (77)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>0<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>38 (35)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Multiples selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Singles selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Known lensed quasars (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>171 (150)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>4 (4)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> detections<sup><em>a</em></sup> (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>43 (34)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1 <em>Gaia</em> detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>86 (77)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>0<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>38 (35)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Multiples selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Singles selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>One of these 43 lenses \u2013 SBS1520+530 \u2013 has one of its two detections due to a nearby star. We keep this in our sample since it would still be selected via this method.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121177050\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177051 id=\"121177051\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-1>5.2.1 Recovering known lenses</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Of the 171 known lenses (including our sample), 4 lenses have 3 <em>Gaia</em> detections, 43 have 2 detections, 86 have 1 detection, and 38 have no detections. Of the 38 with no <em>Gaia</em> detections, only 2 have bright enough images that should be detectable by <em>Gaia</em> \u2013 J0941+0518 and WFI2026-4536 \u2013 with the rest being optically faint mainly due to radio selection.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Applying our selection criteria (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>), we recover 82 lenses (37 <em>Gaia</em> multiples and 45 <em>Gaia</em> singles). 23 of these lenses are quadruply imaged (quad fraction of 28<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{ per cent}$|\u2060</span>), while of all known lenses the quad fraction is 43/171 (25<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{ per cent}$|\u2060</span>). The lenses that we fail to select fall into three categories: separation\u00a0&gt;\u00a04 arcsec, separation \u223c1 arcsec, or high flux ratio doubles. We do not recover the very rare large-separation lenses because of our 4 arcsec <em>Gaia</em> multiple separation cut. The small-separation lenses are missed because of lack of multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections (see Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and in the case of just one <em>Gaia</em> detection, the system is not extended enough and does not pass our morphological classifier. This latter failure also explains the high flux ratio doubles being missed, since the majority of the flux is in one PSF.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177054 id=\"121177054\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-2>5.2.2 Known versus simulated lenses</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our search techniques failed to recover 33 known lenses with <em>Gaia</em> detections. We understand this as the extremes of small- and high-separation images and high flux-ratio doubles. We can verify this and infer which lenses our search is missing by comparing the selected lenses to a simulated sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In particular, we compare to the Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) (OM10 hereafter) simulations which have readily listed image configurations, lensing galaxy parameters, source parameters etc., for 15\u00a0658 mock systems. We limit the entire OM10 sample to those lenses we would expect to be able to find with images brighter than the <em>Gaia</em> threshold. For this criterion we use all lenses that have the faintest image (or second faintest for quads) brighter than <em>i</em> = 21, leaving a catalogue of 2560 mock lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> show histograms of source redshifts and separations, respectively, for our 23 <em>Gaia</em> lens sample, the 82 <em>Gaia</em>-selected known lenses and the reduced OM10 sample. The first plot demonstrates the lack of known lenses at redshifts above <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.2. Two reasons for this are (i) SQLS targetted lenses below this redshift for their statistical sample and (ii) the <em>u</em>-band dropout for quasars above <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.7 makes them more difficult to classify, and at higher redshifts WISE colours tend to become bluer for quasars (as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). The second plot shows that small-separation lenses are being missed. This is naturally expected since these are the hardest to identify in imaging data and to target for follow-up spectroscopy.</p>                        <a id=\"121177058\" scrollto-destination=\"121177058\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=StF8jZ8fvcxs~7NTNCmTUMjiZBYVoEWZQ0lP84IN-mxuTK6haZOIoWynxMQBnDb4Z-~Nk-JtgbUob~e6-5kEETKg11hTQNOWGALeRUV8vL7yxKMoyrDItl-ZlO1RmW5Ep3QpDcZ2FvptwXTbVvBSzpRma7ufIgZG0-9Dyi-bH564Cy~3fD3teyDtif6wn3PzZIEsu0gXwuPvNTvJcEeaHloaDrMUs43Xh454htl1AyfuGubytLapmHRBl5t7CBbs~mbXLco6Dvy5pOvPUzBOKbFSeP8cdJrP2uZDael7RXGjNc8k2XRoNMFwTtq-rU7x0BoYQoTpZo-phX32b0AXbw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"W1 against W1\u2212W2 for all known lenses with at least one Gaia detection and robust WISE photometry, coloured by source redshift. The blue dashed line shows the quasar selection criterion of Stern et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"121177059\" scrollto-destination=\"121177059\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&amp;Signature=GsrLLXxORPUER7Nm-sj8thvtpaCM49TNzAfnxSt6jkioAmxgrHSS8sY332hp~a6czMYMH2Jhfds1LnySugaMzvP3241tMNG00If9e1~DVvg4Dn35kYiaCStubtb-oj-C5Z9XZ6z3dK6XwYWqSVX5HVr94Ahzzz5BSkW3xpsiYgNfQkNQeMJPXcT~KSFbCGjm0swJkcnSChaiAfSNDTayvQiquaUx6cRCCBMtN72o6uneW4wbTYwb4FTNrpdsBK6YbN6wKBhx3WBTNrLZ5iM23mUIJapJZ84Zmh5GBhUbC1kmkWVB-cLy2c0OuBZDiLUc4gpVcjrdX21DMe1RfVNDLQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" OM10 used a lower limit of 0${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$5 for the image separation of their mocks and 4 arcsec as an upper limit.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177060/sty911fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177060\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&Signature=Y0Q8StREHhE-wLgi5ny3x5Xwjvdr9ezwrPUFyOkKVfQpnoehwzmArOv~-uWXm0OZqAe406tY3ghpXiXHI2NK7wvvyynwzO1fsWkmLi9Zbg5KstKrO9tOvUCUMLp62~qo3cLWYa0c9En9PecS4I8HSEUXtz6mG7BsDUEq~pje8bVg2~o12tB4WAvGPrY9Uxww-KrYz-Y0xcavIseiHZxD9GcwdDf2~dF0xFw2och2PyyUYwTI4v1P62Mq68TsdxoiGcQ-gTBNq0MLbjXRJjfcQ5HO4j2kerKisMFMvKD2pnFanqkNCGj46n2ufSlpS7iG09tWuD5gfOlT-I58~x9xBQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177060&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image separation distributions for our <em>Gaia</em> sample, all <em>Gaia</em>-selected lenses, and OM10 mock lenses. OM10 used a lower limit of 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>5 for the image separation of their mocks and 4 arcsec as an upper limit.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&amp;Signature=GsrLLXxORPUER7Nm-sj8thvtpaCM49TNzAfnxSt6jkioAmxgrHSS8sY332hp~a6czMYMH2Jhfds1LnySugaMzvP3241tMNG00If9e1~DVvg4Dn35kYiaCStubtb-oj-C5Z9XZ6z3dK6XwYWqSVX5HVr94Ahzzz5BSkW3xpsiYgNfQkNQeMJPXcT~KSFbCGjm0swJkcnSChaiAfSNDTayvQiquaUx6cRCCBMtN72o6uneW4wbTYwb4FTNrpdsBK6YbN6wKBhx3WBTNrLZ5iM23mUIJapJZ84Zmh5GBhUbC1kmkWVB-cLy2c0OuBZDiLUc4gpVcjrdX21DMe1RfVNDLQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Image separation distributions for our Gaia sample, all Gaia-selected lenses, and OM10 mock lenses. OM10 used a lower limit of 0${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$5 for the image separation of their mocks and 4 arcsec as an upper limit.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177060/sty911fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177060\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&Signature=Y0Q8StREHhE-wLgi5ny3x5Xwjvdr9ezwrPUFyOkKVfQpnoehwzmArOv~-uWXm0OZqAe406tY3ghpXiXHI2NK7wvvyynwzO1fsWkmLi9Zbg5KstKrO9tOvUCUMLp62~qo3cLWYa0c9En9PecS4I8HSEUXtz6mG7BsDUEq~pje8bVg2~o12tB4WAvGPrY9Uxww-KrYz-Y0xcavIseiHZxD9GcwdDf2~dF0xFw2och2PyyUYwTI4v1P62Mq68TsdxoiGcQ-gTBNq0MLbjXRJjfcQ5HO4j2kerKisMFMvKD2pnFanqkNCGj46n2ufSlpS7iG09tWuD5gfOlT-I58~x9xBQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177060&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image separation distributions for our <em>Gaia</em> sample, all <em>Gaia</em>-selected lenses, and OM10 mock lenses. OM10 used a lower limit of 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>5 for the image separation of their mocks and 4 arcsec as an upper limit.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that the quad fraction of the mocks is 18<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{ per cent}$|\u2060</span>, compared to 25<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{ per cent}$|</span> for all known lenses, demonstrating current and previous search biases towards quads \u2013 they are more identifiable once visually inspected and more likely to be caught by search algorithms (e.g. higher likelihood of multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> shows the fainter image magnitude against galaxy magnitude in the <em>i</em> band for our <em>Gaia</em> lens sample. Overlaid are the same values for the entire OM10 mock catalogue. Naturally we are still discovering the brightest lenses on the sky, but we note that there should be many more lenses with bright images with faint galaxies, and faint images with bright galaxies (the top left and the bottom right, respectively). The NIQs identified in this paper can make up the former of these two classes of lens, but require deeper imaging to reveal the lens galaxy. The latter will be missed by searches requiring quasar colour selection. These lenses could be discovered by starting from photometric galaxies and requiring multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections, as Lucey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) have successfully applied to the Pan-STARRS data set.</p>                        <a id=\"121177063\" scrollto-destination=\"121177063\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&amp;Signature=IDlOe5V3y5eRFAPEMm5XKuEvopKSHtVZyUEYgxZoUl90LFHHHQ6coSBo-8K4h8CWAHGyx8TWisziJ-O35xKXm6~fJDO~2fRO440FWpp6OB5q4Nzd3g0TSj-bCIsxAXMUcUJgR5Z38aASMO999GvRQ0Y1Cj3-a0h6wRSV4miur4q8bJ6XDv0DrfP0ki~ePGEZF7DwQZu0OZrBrgkF8u1YjLqevC2CV5d3ibh9VQ9a7HHL-SgHz4QXZrn9t4XFB75GNpDkoRj3KqLa8Q~~tKc7GPJBol0Ol5zu-wNN-hD8XU~~bxxtJBVOM078sZm-msrdOhm-al7P2lniRLcmhC-2Cw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fainter image (second faintest for quads) magnitudes against lensing galaxy magnitudes in the i band. Yellow dots are from our modelled sample and blue is the entire OM10 simulations (no brightness limit).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177063/sty911fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177063\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&Signature=SI2fH8AJmkJ9Z2~XsclHxfbbRjza1RP3PqJMc111RvnA0s6jydESIs7MkgXDdxHLzDRPRADSTybs9M8JtHXJFGNQrcHi3CYKXox5OpalIQTi914-6b462GdXR-TJLraGde0nr1CnOcVXm2REDzkWAST0GwYuMzWLVnJ4Yhwd7TXwituVlrdgP5umbhDwtNQtdo4j4K~SAu9dAdoe7BySMku4xyAj2xniQFHA0kv4LRWvOR49TNcZhvSUqDQkAtftapfWwvKb3jk3K7OSVhmghb1twvhFNTfgykNr5Zn0XwVvSr3RpnETmTEfbQrvQGLNOTXa6C5RtDKVdEx4jkb~hA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177063&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fainter image (second faintest for quads) magnitudes against lensing galaxy magnitudes in the <em>i</em> band. Yellow dots are from our modelled sample and blue is the entire OM10 simulations (no brightness limit).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&amp;Signature=IDlOe5V3y5eRFAPEMm5XKuEvopKSHtVZyUEYgxZoUl90LFHHHQ6coSBo-8K4h8CWAHGyx8TWisziJ-O35xKXm6~fJDO~2fRO440FWpp6OB5q4Nzd3g0TSj-bCIsxAXMUcUJgR5Z38aASMO999GvRQ0Y1Cj3-a0h6wRSV4miur4q8bJ6XDv0DrfP0ki~ePGEZF7DwQZu0OZrBrgkF8u1YjLqevC2CV5d3ibh9VQ9a7HHL-SgHz4QXZrn9t4XFB75GNpDkoRj3KqLa8Q~~tKc7GPJBol0Ol5zu-wNN-hD8XU~~bxxtJBVOM078sZm-msrdOhm-al7P2lniRLcmhC-2Cw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fainter image (second faintest for quads) magnitudes against lensing galaxy magnitudes in the i band. Yellow dots are from our modelled sample and blue is the entire OM10 simulations (no brightness limit).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177063/sty911fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177063\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&Signature=SI2fH8AJmkJ9Z2~XsclHxfbbRjza1RP3PqJMc111RvnA0s6jydESIs7MkgXDdxHLzDRPRADSTybs9M8JtHXJFGNQrcHi3CYKXox5OpalIQTi914-6b462GdXR-TJLraGde0nr1CnOcVXm2REDzkWAST0GwYuMzWLVnJ4Yhwd7TXwituVlrdgP5umbhDwtNQtdo4j4K~SAu9dAdoe7BySMku4xyAj2xniQFHA0kv4LRWvOR49TNcZhvSUqDQkAtftapfWwvKb3jk3K7OSVhmghb1twvhFNTfgykNr5Zn0XwVvSr3RpnETmTEfbQrvQGLNOTXa6C5RtDKVdEx4jkb~hA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177063&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fainter image (second faintest for quads) magnitudes against lensing galaxy magnitudes in the <em>i</em> band. Yellow dots are from our modelled sample and blue is the entire OM10 simulations (no brightness limit).</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121177064 id=\"121177064\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented the discovery of 24 gravitationally lensed quasars; 13 are discovered by having multiple <em>Gaia</em> components, 10 as <em>Gaia</em> detections near morphological galaxies, and 1 from an emission line identification in an SDSS galaxy spectrum. All of these systems have well-resolved images in ground-based imaging and are bright, lending themselves to monitoring and subsequent time delay cosmography studies (Treu &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Our sample includes four quadruply imaged lenses and one double lens which shows a blue Einstein ring in deep CFHT data. One quad, J0030-1525, requires high-resolution imaging to verify our understanding that one image is highly demagnified, by a factor of \u223c14. Four of our lenses \u2013 J0140-1152, J0146-1133, J0235-2433, and J0259-2338 \u2013 have been independently identified using a complementary <em>Gaia</em> and WISE selection by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) and Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparing our sample of lensed quasars to simulations, we show that we are not sensitive to arcsecond-separation lenses and those at redshifts beyond the <em>u</em>-band dropout. This is due to colour selection and the bias from visually inspecting a large number of candidates. This biases our sample towards systems with bright lensing galaxies and quads, and away from small-separation lenses and bright doubles that are often confused for stars. The second <em>Gaia</em> data release on 2018 April 25 will not only help increase the completeness of lens searches through detection of more lensed quasar images and colour information from the blue and red photometers, but also drastically reduce the number of candidates that must be inspected. Further data release, including proper motion information, will further remove contaminants.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) predict several thousand lensed quasars to be detectable using LSST (Large Synoptic Survey Telescope), however to confirm such large numbers of lenses to become useful astrophysical and cosmological tools, we must ensure we select lenses efficiently and in a complete manner. We have demonstrated that combining <em>Gaia</em>, WISE, SDSS, and Pan-STARRS data with pixel-based modelling can efficiently select new lenses \u2013 a 57<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{ per cent}$|</span> success rate (including binaries).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121177068 id=\"121177068\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">CAL and RGM would like to thank the STFC, and MWA acknowledges support from the STFC in the form of an Ernest Rutherford Fellowship. This work has made use of data from the European Space Agency (ESA) mission <em>Gaia</em> (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia</a>), processed by the <em>Gaia</em> Data Processing and Analysis Consortium (DPAC, <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/gaia/dpac/consortium\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/gaia/dpac/consortium</a>). Funding for the DPAC has been provided by national institutions, in particular the institutions participating in the <em>Gaia</em> Multilateral Agreement. The Pan-STARRS1 Surveys (PS1) and the PS1 public science archive have been made possible through contributions by the Institute for Astronomy, the University of Hawaii, the Pan-STARRS Project Office, the Max-Planck Society and its participating institutes, the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, Heidelberg, and the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics, Garching, The Johns Hopkins University, Durham University, the University of Edinburgh, the Queen\u2019s University Belfast, the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, the Las Cumbres Observatory Global Telescope Network Incorporated, the National Central University of Taiwan, the Space Telescope Science Institute, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration under Grant No. NNX08AR22G issued through the Planetary Science Division of the NASA Science Mission Directorate, the National Science Foundation Grant No. AST-1238877, the University of Maryland, Eotvos Lorand University (ELTE), the Los Alamos National Laboratory, and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation. This publication makes use of data products from the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer, which is a joint project of the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory/California Institute of Technology, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121177070 id=\"121177070\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abbott</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T. $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-body               <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Figures &amp; tables</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"audio\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Audio</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"supplementary-data\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Supplementary Data</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal><i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i><span>Cite</span></a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Cameron A Lemon, Matthew W Auger, Richard G McMahon, Fernanda Ostrovski,  Gravitationally lensed quasars in <em>Gaia</em> \u2013 II. Discovery of 24 lensed quasars, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 479, Issue 4, October 2018, Pages 5060\u20135074, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty911\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty911</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121176957 id=\"121176957\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery, spectroscopic confirmation, and preliminary characterization of 24 gravitationally lensed quasars identified using <em>Gaia</em> observations. Candidates were selected in the Pan-STARRS footprint with quasar-like WISE colours or as photometric quasars from Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), requiring either multiple detections in <em>Gaia</em> or a single <em>Gaia</em> detection near a morphological galaxy. The Pan-STARRS <em>grizY</em> images were modelled for the most promising candidates and 60 candidate systems were followed up with the William Herschel Telescope. 13 of the lenses were discovered as <em>Gaia</em> multiples and 10 as single <em>Gaia</em> detections near galaxies. We also discover 1 lens identified through a quasar emission line in an SDSS galaxy spectrum. The lenses have median image separation 2.13 arcsec and the source redshifts range from 1.06 to 3.36. 4 systems are quadruply imaged and 20 are doubly imaged. Deep CFHT data reveal an Einstein ring in one double system. We also report 12 quasar pairs, 10 of which have components at the same redshift and require further follow-up to rule out the lensing hypothesis. We compare the properties of these lenses and other known lenses recovered by our search method to a complete sample of simulated lenses to show the lenses we are missing are mainly those with small separations and higher source redshifts. The initial <em>Gaia</em> data release only catalogues all images of \u223c30\u2009per\u2009cent of known bright lensed quasars, however the improved completeness of <em>Gaia</em> data release 2 will help find all bright lensed quasars on the sky.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: observational&quot;\">methods: observational</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: general&quot;\">quasars: general</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121176959 id=\"121176959\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">There are currently fewer than 40 known gravitationally lensed quasars with image separations over 2 arcsec. The multiple images of these bright wider-separation systems can be monitored to determine time delays, which are used to calculate a time delay distance and hence infer the Hubble constant (Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1966</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). This is a promising method to shed light on the apparent tension between local distance measurements (Riess et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and CMB measurements (Planck Collaboration XIII <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Lensed quasars are also powerful tools to probe the many facets of galaxy evolution: lens mass distributions (Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Mediavilla et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), source quasar accretion discs (Rauch &amp; Blandford <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Pooley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), source quasar host galaxies (Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Bayliss et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Ding et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), etc. However the results of all these studies are currently hindered by the dearth of known lensed quasars.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The first Pan-STARRS data release (Chambers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) has provided arcsecond-resolution, multiwavelength (<em>grizY</em>) imaging of three-quarters of the sky. This provides the perfect data set to increase the number of bright lensed quasars through area alone. Furthermore the multiwavelength data allow characterization and pre-selection of the most promising candidates to spectroscopically follow up through the use of residual features, goodness of fit, and SED similarity. While many techniques exist for identifying lenses from purely photometric data (Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), all are plagued by contaminant systems that resemble lensed quasars. These include compact star-forming galaxy pairs, binary quasars, and quasars projected close to blue stars and galaxies. Additionally, the resolution of ground-based imaging data often blends the separate components of lensed quasars into just one catalogued object. This blending by the point spread function (PSF) on the scale of the image separation leads to contaminant systems being confused for lensed quasars. One way to overcome this blending issue is to use the excellent resolution of <em>Gaia</em> (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), which is able to separate two point sources separated by \u223c0.1 arcsec (Fabricius et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Only a catalogue of detections is currently released from the <em>Gaia</em> collaboration (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>), however this is enough to quickly reduce the number of contaminants. Even though <em>Gaia</em> has not catalogued all components of close pairs (Arenou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), the knowledge that a point source exists in a system removes some star-forming galaxy contaminants from the search.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The selection, follow-up, and modelling of lensed quasars using Pan-STARRS and <em>Gaia</em> data form the basis of this paper. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> we describe the search techniques and the starting photometric quasar catalogues. Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> explains the observations and their outcomes, and in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a> we create light profile and mass models for the systems. Finally we discuss the individual systems and summarize our findings in Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) magnitudes are quoted in the AB system. The conversions from Vega to AB for ALLWISE data are <em>W</em>1<sub>AB</sub> = <em>W</em>1<sub>Vega</sub> + 2.699 and <em>W</em>2<sub>AB</sub> = <em>W</em>2<sub>Vega</sub> + 3.339, which are given in Jarrett et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and in the ALLWISE explanatory supplement. When required, a flat cosmology with \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> was used.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121176963 id=\"121176963\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 LENS CANDIDATE SELECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The following section describes the candidate selection process. The declination range was limited to \u2273\u00a0\u2212\u00a030, i.e. requiring <em>grizY</em> imaging from Pan-STARRS. For the majority of searches we required the systems to have a galactic latitude, |<em>b</em>|\u00a0&gt;\u00a015, however in some right ascension ranges (RA \u223c 80, along the galactic anticentre) this was relaxed. Before a final sample was established, the local <em>Gaia</em> stellar density for each candidate was required to be less than 50\u00a0000 stars per square degree (calculated by counting <em>Gaia</em> sources within a 100 arcsec radius), in order to remove star clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two quasar candidate catalogues are created, and two <em>Gaia</em>-based selection methods are applied to these catalogues to generate our final sample, as described in the following subsections.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121176966 id=\"121176966\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Photometric quasar candidate catalogues</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121176967 id=\"121176967\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-1>2.1.1 I. WISE mid-infrared colours</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Stern et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) have shown that the W1 and W2 bands of WISE (Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) can be used to select AGN by applying the colour criterion of W1\u2212W2 \u2265 0.16 (AB). One advantage of this selection technique is its simplicity and effectiveness (Wu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), however a downside for our purposes is that lensed quasar photometry can be strongly affected by the lensing galaxy, leading to WISE colours bluer than those of isolated quasars.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To overcome this, we apply a looser WISE criterion of W1\u2212W2 \u2265 \u22120.14. With this limit we do not expect an unreasonable number of contaminants still meeting our <em>Gaia</em> detection criteria of Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>. The main contaminant created by this lower limit is quasar+star projections.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We ensure that the WISE detections are robust in W1 and W2 by requiring catalogue uncertainties and a W1 value brighter than 18.2. After matching to Pan-STARRS and keeping objects with <em>i</em>-band PSF magnitudes brighter than 21, our initial WISE-selected quasar candidate list has 1298\u00a0877 objects with |<em>b</em>|\u00a0&gt;\u00a015.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121176971 id=\"121176971\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-2>2.1.2 II. SDSS GMM photometric quasars</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Recent papers (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Ostrovski in preparation) have shown that the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) imaging data still contain bright lensed quasars, which had not been targetted for spectroscopy and hence were missed by the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the SDSS imaging data set includes <em>u</em>-band data \u2013 which are particularly useful for selecting AGN \u2013 we create a complementary catalogue to the WISE selection above by applying Gaussian mixture modelling (GMM) classification to SDSS objects as in Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This is a morphology-independent selection based on <em>u</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>g, g</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>i</em>, and <em>i</em> \u2212W1 colours. Classification is divided into four classes: stars, galaxies, and low- and high-redshift quasars (<em>z</em> \u2272 2.7 and <em>z</em> \u2273 2.7, respectively). This classification is applied to all SDSS objects with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$psfMag\\_i\\lt 21$|\u2060</span>. Our final GMM quasar candidate catalogue is composed of all objects that have a combined (low and high redshift) quasar probability\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.5. This results in 1158557 quasar candidates.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121176974 id=\"121176974\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Morphology selection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Once a set of photometric quasar candidates is selected, we attempt to remove the objects that are not lensed quasars \u2013 mainly isolated quasars or misclassified star-forming galaxies. To this end we use <em>Gaia</em> data, which have a spatial resolution of \u223c0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>1 (Fabricius et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). <em>Gaia</em> is built to detect stars in our galaxy, but naturally detects bright quasars as a by-product. Therefore we search our quasar candidate catalogues for objects in which multiple <em>Gaia</em> sources are detected, as would be expected for multiple-imaged quasars. While this does not remove quasar+star projections from our candidates, it removes many star-forming galaxies and isolated quasars, since at most one <em>Gaia</em> detection is expected for these contaminants.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since <em>Gaia</em> does not reliably detect all images of most lensed quasars, we also describe a simple morphology selection using just one <em>Gaia</em> detection (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). While this selection naturally removes fewer contaminants, it is able to recover 45 known lenses. The details of the two methods are described below. They are both applied to each of the quasar catalogues described in\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>; Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the number of candidates each technique and quasar catalogue produced, given the selection criteria. Note that the numbers are not exclusive.</p>                        <a id=\"121176977\" scrollto-destination=\"121176977\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidate numbers for the two quasar catalogues and the two <em>Gaia</em> morphological selection methods.</p></div> </div><div per sq. deg\u00a0</td><td><strong>8447</strong>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"2\">SINGLES\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> matches &lt;4 mas\u00a0</td><td>80\u00a0595\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Stellar density\u00a0&lt;\u00a050\u00a0000 per sq. deg\u00a0</td><td><strong>80\u00a0206</strong>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>SDSS GMM quasars</em>\u00a0</td><td>1158\u00a0557\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"2\">MULTIPLES\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> matches\u00a0&lt;\u00a02 arcsec\u00a0</td><td>686\u00a0311\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> matches within 4 arcsec of each other\u00a0</td><td>24\u00a0851\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> AEN\u00a0&lt;\u00a010 mas\u00a0</td><td>24\u00a0765\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Stellar density\u00a0&lt;\u00a050\u00a0000 per sq. deg\u00a0</td><td><strong>24\u00a0749</strong>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"2\">SINGLES\u00a0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> matches\u00a0&lt;\u00a04 arcsec\u00a0</td><td>710\u00a0052\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> singles with <em>r</em><sub>PSF</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>r</em><sub>KRON</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>54\u00a0352\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>Gaia</em> AEN\u00a0&lt;\u00a010 mas\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0491\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Stellar density\u00a0&lt;\u00a050\u00a0000 per sq. deg\u00a0</td><td><strong>50\u00a0488</strong>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121176977\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121176978 id=\"121176978\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-1>2.2.1 Multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our first selection technique is to find quasar candidates with multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections. We require at least two <em>Gaia</em> detections within 4 arcsec of each other. Lensed quasars with separations above this are very rare (e.g. Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and the number of contaminant systems increases roughly proportionally to the maximum image separation allowed in a search. Furthermore <em>Gaia</em> is most useful at combating the blending of smaller-separation systems in ground-based optical survey data, in which lenses with images separated by more than 4 arcsec should already be deblended. This technique is applied in a two-step process: first all quasar candidates are matched to <em>Gaia</em> within 2 arcsec of the Pan-STARRS detection and secondly this is matched to <em>Gaia</em> again within 4 arcsec of the initial <em>Gaia</em> position. We choose the first matching distance to be only 2 arcsec since this retains all known lenses with two <em>Gaia</em> detections while removing some single quasar candidates projected near stars with <em>Gaia</em> detections.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121176980 id=\"121176980\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-2>2.2.2 <em>Gaia</em> detection near morphological galaxy</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Cross-matching <em>Gaia</em> to known lensed quasars (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) demonstrates that only one in five small-separation lensed quasars have all quasar images detected by <em>Gaia</em>, even when all images should be detected. Although this fraction increases with separation (one-third at the largest separations; Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), requiring multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections will miss the majority of lenses. One way to find some of these 'missing' lenses is to perform a search depending on only one <em>Gaia</em> detection. We do this but require a morphological galaxy within 4 arcsec of the quasar candidate, removing contamination from wider-separation star+quasar projections. If the single <em>Gaia</em> detection is indeed a quasar, a bright galaxy within 4 arcsec is a strong candidate for acting as a foreground lens. We crossmatch our quasar candidates to <em>Gaia</em> within 4 arcsec and then back to Pan-STARRS within 4 arcsec of our original quasar candidate but requiring the criterion of <em>r<sub>PSF</sub></em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>r<sub>KRON</sub></em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.2 for the new match. This extended object can be the original quasar candidate.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121176982 id=\"121176982\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Final lens candidate catalogue</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">After applying the <em>Gaia</em> multiple and single detection techniques to the two quasar candidate catalogues, we apply two further filters. The first is requiring the astrometric excess noise (AEN; Lindegren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) for each <em>Gaia</em> detection to be less than 10 mas. The AEN is a useful indicator for point source/galaxy separation (Belokurov et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Koposov, Belokurov &amp; Torrealba <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) which holds for known lensed quasars (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Therefore we can remove many star-forming galaxies from our search by applying the simple cut AEN&lt;10 mas. The second filter is removing all candidates with local <em>Gaia</em> stellar densities above 50\u2002000 stars per square degree. This is calculated by counting all <em>Gaia</em> detections within 100 arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The catalogues are then stacked and duplicates from the two quasar candidate selection techniques are removed, leaving 109\u00a0941 <em>Gaia</em> singles and 31\u00a0486 <em>Gaia</em> pairs. After selecting \u223c200 of the most promising candidates through visual inspection, the Pan-STARRS <em>grizY</em> images are modelled simultaneously as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>. This is to ensure the postulated quasar images have similar colours and to prioritize systems with residual features consistent with a lensing galaxy.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121176985 id=\"121176985\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectra of 60 candidates were taken with the Intermediate dispersion Spectrograph and Imaging System (ISIS) on the 4.2-m William Herschel Telescope (WHT) on the nights of 2017 March 31, April 1, September 12 and 13 . Since we only needed to identify broad emission line features, we used the low-resolution gratings, R158 (121 \u00c5 mm<sup>\u22121</sup>/1.81 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>) for the red arm and B300 (64 \u00c5 mm<sup>\u22121</sup>/0.86 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>) for the blue arm. Each lens candidate was positioned along a 1-arcsec-wide slit to capture both quasar images. Multiple position angles were used for one quad candidate, J1721+8842.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After masking cosmic rays and subtracting the sky background, the spectra were visually inspected for broad emission lines in the separated peaks and 1-D spectra were extracted using Gaussian apertures with 0.5 arcsec width.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121176988 id=\"121176988\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Results</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> shows a summary of the observations with sky positions, candidate selection method, outcome of the observation, and WISE and <em>Gaia</em> magnitudes.</p>                        <a id=\"121176990\" scrollto-destination=\"121176990\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of observations. NIQ=nearly identical quasar, assigned to systems of quasars at the same redshift but without photometric detection of a lensing galaxy. Selection shows the quasar catalogue and <em>Gaia</em> technique with which the candidate was selected: S=single, D=double, T=triple. All dates are in 2017. WISE magnitudes and colours are given in the AB system.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Selection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>W</em>1\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>W</em>2, <em>W</em>1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>Gaia</em> G<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Date, Exp. 600s\u00a0</td><td>quasar+star\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121176990\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have classified 24 objects as lensed quasars since the spectra reveal the presence of (at least) two quasars at the same redshift and the pixel modelling of the Pan-STARRS images reveals a lensing galaxy. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows Pan-STARRS <em>gri</em> cutouts of the confirmed lens systems with <em>Gaia</em> detections overlaid. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> shows the component spectra for each lens. We are able to establish the lens galaxy redshift for four lenses.</p>                        <a id=\"121176992\" scrollto-destination=\"121176992\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=t2b8Nn-jrxPKFUwH5Kb-g5-Th-WOjkhVxACI69qcn4RuVvpz31dJp9DbkUvtuTMn-5AqDC6YOwRsOq2FLlmZxfoN~PebFLKfMNEeWlQay5v9BUtWncV7T2WSJjkXKYHmb5x1XB1~vtXHyv0tqx--TDxbJltE0Z5rnoXeDnel4sf6dLcyt1SIl3qpymG6VSEtcH8OlhkE3bTJ4Zf-HKD-GUmfau-wB6e5WH~GXN5R8frqoqbSREWHTnTF85mvP7Q9mfCuF5smR1ZtrBBBMNTZq4xiOCwB7LotqFLIUpKFK5sFVvripbRx9yeqJU2XOi6xaok1Cq9MIkQdrsQ-s0p2Rw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS gri colour images of the confirmed lenses with Gaia detections overlaid with red crosses. Quasar emission lines are labelled in blue, and lens galaxy absorption lines in green where identified.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We further discover 10 systems consisting of pairs of quasars at the same redshift, shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. Their spectra are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. However in these systems, the residuals after PSF subtraction do not convincingly demonstrate a lens, or the spectral features rule out the lensing hypothesis. See Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a> for details on individual systems. Summaries of key characteristics of lensed quasars and nearly identical quasars are shown in Tables <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"121176995\" scrollto-destination=\"121176995\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=lOUFPGVGnmT96Afimd3AesNEjO3BpYvmlvAotuxyIKokDE--KpVwdTLKXWJmVv9B7d27z41VXdgnbV1b8eXQIOiNBRCXCgdc-SYmj~TE-lKmbJzWpYyl7uUzb--WDC73CB8PEQ5bV0w0o~s9YeG~GismHbTQDQJy2cA2kmBDCM8IiXvEPEyLdqwkuC8CkaFouAnpqGHWDLalAHJjTxuTKrkv0zE7PIzn8mop4NyiQqGtNReEmOJATWshK64Wu073rNSYK0zN25z19POD27h8H8OMAfaK1bdSxL~eJ4pwffnvQRlyD8~jYvqZZ~~LXpqbPjV6UAJRD44D67~ygEWsrg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS gri colour images of the nearly identical quasars. 18.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1831+5447\u00a0</td><td>1.07\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>2.32\u00a0</td><td>18.80, 18.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2124+1632\u00a0</td><td>1.28\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>3.02\u00a0</td><td>18.11, 18.40\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2305+3714\u00a0</td><td>1.78\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>2.20\u00a0</td><td>17.03, 18.32\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2332\u22121852\u00a0</td><td>1.49\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>1.97\u00a0</td><td>18.76, 18.93\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121176997\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                        <a id=\"121176998\" scrollto-destination=\"121176998\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div
