(\u2033)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>i</em><sub>mag</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J0127\u22121441\u00a0</td><td>1.76\u00a0</td><td>2.96\u00a0</td><td>19.30\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0139+3526\u00a0</td><td>0.65\u00a0</td><td>2.22\u00a0</td><td>18.49\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0140+4107\u00a0</td><td>2.50\u00a0</td><td>1.44\u00a0</td><td>16.94\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0740+2926\u00a0</td><td>0.98\u00a0</td><td>2.59\u00a0</td><td>18.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0812+3349\u00a0</td><td>1.49\u00a0</td><td>1.99\u00a0</td><td>19.12\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1139+4143\u00a0</td><td>2.23\u00a0</td><td>2.30\u00a0</td><td>18.86\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1540+4445\u00a0</td><td>0.61\u00a0</td><td>2.74\u00a0</td><td>19.21\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1821+6005\u00a0</td><td>2.05\u00a0</td><td>1.48\u00a0</td><td>19.34\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2032\u22122358\u00a0</td><td>1.64\u00a0</td><td>1.91\u00a0</td><td>18.40\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2057+0217\u00a0</td><td>1.52\u00a0</td><td>1.06\u00a0</td><td>18.96\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>source</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Sep. (\u2033)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>i</em><sub>mag</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J0127\u22121441\u00a0</td><td>1.76\u00a0</td><td>2.96\u00a0</td><td>19.30\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0139+3526\u00a0</td><td>0.65\u00a0</td><td>2.22\u00a0</td><td>18.49\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0140+4107\u00a0</td><td>2.50\u00a0</td><td>1.44\u00a0</td><td>16.94\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0740+2926\u00a0</td><td>0.98\u00a0</td><td>2.59\u00a0</td><td>18.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0812+3349\u00a0</td><td>1.49\u00a0</td><td>1.99\u00a0</td><td>19.12\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1139+4143\u00a0</td><td>2.23\u00a0</td><td>2.30\u00a0</td><td>18.86\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1540+4445\u00a0</td><td>0.61\u00a0</td><td>2.74\u00a0</td><td>19.21\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1821+6005\u00a0</td><td>2.05\u00a0</td><td>1.48\u00a0</td><td>19.34\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2032\u22122358\u00a0</td><td>1.64\u00a0</td><td>1.91\u00a0</td><td>18.40\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2057+0217\u00a0</td><td>1.52\u00a0</td><td>1.06\u00a0</td><td>18.96\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121176998\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121176999 id=\"121176999\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 MODELLING</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121177000 id=\"121177000\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Pixel modelling</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section we model the Pan-STARRS <em>grizY</em> imaging data for each lens system to derive simple component shapes, positions, and colours. In the next section we use the image and galaxy positions and flux measurements to fit simple lens models to each system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The PSF is derived by fitting a Moffat profile (Moffat <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1969</a>) to a nearby star. The <em>grizY</em> Pan-STARRS images are modelled simultaneously with each quasar image fit with a PSF, and galaxies fit with S\u00e9rsic profiles (S\u00e9rsic <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1963</a>) convolved with the PSF. In all lens systems, the presence of a lens galaxy is apparent from the colour image, except for J0630-1201 and J1606-2333. The free parameters for the pixel modelling are the positions of the quasar images and the lensing galaxy, as well as the flattening, size, and S\u00e9rsic index of the galaxy, all of which we assume to be the same across bands. The log likelihood is sampled using the <span class=\"small-caps\">emcee</span> package Foreman-Mackey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) to determine statistical uncertainties. Finally the fitting is repeated with a different PSF star to determine the systematic error for a possible PSF mismatch.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> shows the Pan-STARRS <em>gri</em> images and the residuals after modelling each system as the relevant sum of quasars and galaxies. Astrometry and photometry for all available bands are given in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1a\" data-open=\"tbl1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"121177004\" scrollto-destination=\"121177004\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=uLx1A7vHnf2LdcwoWOeQWar~CQ-uVNKsnF6ipntzQoDrjQq9zQD5BksAb-xPRZ5jpfR0WS8bWoPEI3x0VYb8H3FRex4v7fpG3VXsNHId9sl9TUsNdg3A9LdP6uyPBsKJ8vDdT2Hnsx8fHU~1LNx354BZpxqMIKVqo4sgMTJLlm-7t9OkHN~m6ap1R-Ls8WMjCxn~SF5Rf4CRCcKMkA~~UnTL5v8C5q8UvQvirg0l4uMhiaGl8I2xZuXVBmEz08xh8u5nFyMIFLKizoqW6QChKxaJ~OO-I2LeNYF9A7QVsBaAqFYdtbeuCO8F~oWDRc5LNJOsDGU3Ijm8tkp55tLQJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pixel modelling of the confirmed lenses. Left to right: gri data, model, gri PSF-subtracted, and r-band residuals. Blue crosses indicate the positions of quasar images and red plusses mark the locations of lensing galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177004/sty911fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177004\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&Signature=nEuU6r8nwm~HQEZjbASoDFkBrqAR9KWA2VE9Yf5bZbaXr5~s6vrJjBqNNyKZ5v5bRUbPt~tOxxZmKVjuvNlTvynYRtq2l07x-ARkudsGdDuMdhrOiTUSAwscZKQ7TdcCkQ5EzcVAotygFEX68sK-SLcK0zMR1CdV71gAOYdK~hSnW8AmT4~~s16JVPWReICFEE6Y5KrEsmm57hviKOI2jDxvcq91gxXt5ub9A6Z-hG1M6th~7GbBS3vN3ZMsf5XXft0SOX36kOhxE1gq7r0V-i1ItuU2F1dumO8s1yWlbmF9kYH07WkM4eKnjbBGEcX63M32TshR3DiT-aZNAIB0bg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177004&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pixel modelling of the confirmed lenses. Left to right: <em>gri</em> data, model, <em>gri</em> PSF-subtracted, and <em>r</em>-band residuals. Blue crosses indicate the positions of quasar images and red plusses mark the locations of lensing galaxies.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=uLx1A7vHnf2LdcwoWOeQWar~CQ-uVNKsnF6ipntzQoDrjQq9zQD5BksAb-xPRZ5jpfR0WS8bWoPEI3x0VYb8H3FRex4v7fpG3VXsNHId9sl9TUsNdg3A9LdP6uyPBsKJ8vDdT2Hnsx8fHU~1LNx354BZpxqMIKVqo4sgMTJLlm-7t9OkHN~m6ap1R-Ls8WMjCxn~SF5Rf4CRCcKMkA~~UnTL5v8C5q8UvQvirg0l4uMhiaGl8I2xZuXVBmEz08xh8u5nFyMIFLKizoqW6QChKxaJ~OO-I2LeNYF9A7QVsBaAqFYdtbeuCO8F~oWDRc5LNJOsDGU3Ijm8tkp55tLQJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pixel modelling of the confirmed lenses. Left to right: gri data, model, gri PSF-subtracted, and r-band residuals. Blue crosses indicate the positions of quasar images and red plusses mark the locations of lensing galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177004/sty911fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177004\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&Signature=nEuU6r8nwm~HQEZjbASoDFkBrqAR9KWA2VE9Yf5bZbaXr5~s6vrJjBqNNyKZ5v5bRUbPt~tOxxZmKVjuvNlTvynYRtq2l07x-ARkudsGdDuMdhrOiTUSAwscZKQ7TdcCkQ5EzcVAotygFEX68sK-SLcK0zMR1CdV71gAOYdK~hSnW8AmT4~~s16JVPWReICFEE6Y5KrEsmm57hviKOI2jDxvcq91gxXt5ub9A6Z-hG1M6th~7GbBS3vN3ZMsf5XXft0SOX36kOhxE1gq7r0V-i1ItuU2F1dumO8s1yWlbmF9kYH07WkM4eKnjbBGEcX63M32TshR3DiT-aZNAIB0bg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177004&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pixel modelling of the confirmed lenses. Left to right: <em>gri</em> data, model, <em>gri</em> PSF-subtracted, and <em>r</em>-band residuals. Blue crosses indicate the positions of quasar images and red plusses mark the locations of lensing galaxies.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121177005 id=\"121177005\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Mass modelling</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We fit all the systems with singular isothermal elipsoids (SIE) using our own <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span>-based image-plane modelling code, which has been checked for consistency with <em>lensmodel</em> (Keeton <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). We use the two-step process of modelling the pixels to find positions and fluxes, and then deriving a lens model. This is to ensure that if the system is not well-described by a singular isothermal ellipsoid, it does not affect the PSF subtraction. Furthermore we can quantify the chi-squared contributions fromTAB positions and flux ratios robustly. For all the doubly imaged lenses, we start from two image positions and a galaxy position (six parameters). However, to constrain a singular isothermal ellipsoid (galaxy position, mass, ellipticity, position angle and source position; seven parameters), we require one further observable. For this we use the image flux ratio. We take the median flux ratio from the <em>griz</em> bands and include a 20 per cent uncertainty on the input fluxes since optical flux ratios depend not only on the lensing geometry but also on extinction, quasar variability over the time delay, microlensing, etc. Using these pixel-based measurements and their uncertainties, the lens parameters are inferred through image-plane sampling. Given the extra information in quads, we are able to use more realistic models with more parameters. We use SIE+shear models for these systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lens model parameters (medians with 1\u03c3 limits) and chi-squared contributions are listed in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. For the three quadruply imaged lensed quasars, we include a 50 per cent uncertainty on the input fluxes for the two saddle point images in each system, in accordance with their increased susceptibility to microlensing (Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"121177008\" scrollto-destination=\"121177008\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Median parameter values with 1\u03c3 uncertainties for mass models and light profiles. b=Einstein radius, PA= position angle (north of west), q = axis ratio, \u03bc = total source magnification. <sup><em>a</em></sup>The mass model and galaxy light profile for J0030-1525 are based on better seeing VST-ATLAS data (Shanks et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" no-formula-id\">|$4.5_{4.3}^{4.9}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121177008\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Systems with significantly elliptical SIE fits and a large image-position chi-squared are indicative of a strong external shear if the lens is not elliptical in the photometry.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121177010 id=\"121177010\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121177011 id=\"121177011\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Notes on individual systems</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177012 id=\"121177012\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-1>5.1.1 J0030\u22121525</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The Pan-STARRS <em>gri</em> image for this object shows two bright PSFs and a galaxy significantly offset from where it should lie to create a double-image system. However, a better seeing VST <em>i</em>-band image (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>) resolves four objects including a faint blue PSF next to an extended red object. This is consistent with a flux-ratio anomaly fold-configuration quad with the faint PSF being the counterimage. We model the Pan-STARRS data for photometry of A+B, C, and D+G, given in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1a\" data-open=\"tbl1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>. However, for the mass model we use the VST <em>r</em>-band data given its excellent seeing and resolution of the counterimage. The PSF is inferred from the data due to the lack of a nearby star. We find that the data are fit by models with the merging pair consisting of a bright image north-west of a faint image or vice versa. The former is much more plausible, given that saddle points are more commonly demagnified than maxima and minima (Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) and so this is the mass model we report in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. The best fit mass model gives flux ratios of \u223c7:7:3:1 while the measured flux ratios are \u223c7:0.5:4:1, i.e. a 14\u00d7 decrease for image B.</p>                        <a id=\"121177014\" scrollto-destination=\"121177014\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=1F8ZPrBciVZT2ZDeEnEWyioWQDue7jbIF1MWyffmu9Hw6McDi25sVpk8W3~YY9PR~oHf5ny~ilxHD3APbJufxYdLqDwRrSAoJ9AnwUiQcnmB7xfjs-~PSPyDd8K45T8GHPeiv6StlY19s2pG4HIGosn0ZcA6Gpwg5a6u8X9eluFNvJTCMa2GCrRVZ0hEdaCsfazM71RlNmN3g6arAAv3mQ-d~mv9bunM6bZfUA0ToLcit3BSrZWUppFkCwvns1tPpk1azB-s4AoKLtgpMmQcT2ACJxXOZY360ePQaYRiwJlVrISyHKmL0UIuhK6Wdd4zr7Hp7WpnYf-c~eaukKCR4Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"From the left: PSJ0030-1525 VST grz colour image; 0.42-arcsec-seeing r-band VST image; 4PSFs+galaxy model with PSF positions overlaid; residuals after model subtraction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177014/sty911fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177014\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&Signature=BpqJwZFH8eQTN5BmqrSBg~lNOXrMW5ZKXPrKSjeoCtKb6xepUxv4x6FiSIm71y9sPYnYRX3~s2uJxmTJy1VkV5~4CCpDIoRALmeONjnmW5wgUhd5UnycoIsFHZsf1jpI6odhrQiaw3cJx4AVK386tNK5~mdSOizbBImJNNlRRJt7gCHOrrG~NTrjTRvq2AbUT2Ur9xSbuyL060~RC7stELC0JxxwHqcuxeVN2N84vQ-Vwx4PLc3UyGfZTuyDgu9BjOcGNDVgzJT98UsVQknO0O5Z8ZRnEpfbMwE5uHAprTNWkbSQEejUVNgWx0TE1pABpfX6GzocM0rTjbFHU4Jx3Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177014&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">From the left: PSJ0030-1525 VST <em>grz</em> colour image; 0.42-arcsec-seeing <em>r</em>-band VST image; 4PSFs+galaxy model with PSF positions overlaid; residuals after model subtraction.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=1F8ZPrBciVZT2ZDeEnEWyioWQDue7jbIF1MWyffmu9Hw6McDi25sVpk8W3~YY9PR~oHf5ny~ilxHD3APbJufxYdLqDwRrSAoJ9AnwUiQcnmB7xfjs-~PSPyDd8K45T8GHPeiv6StlY19s2pG4HIGosn0ZcA6Gpwg5a6u8X9eluFNvJTCMa2GCrRVZ0hEdaCsfazM71RlNmN3g6arAAv3mQ-d~mv9bunM6bZfUA0ToLcit3BSrZWUppFkCwvns1tPpk1azB-s4AoKLtgpMmQcT2ACJxXOZY360ePQaYRiwJlVrISyHKmL0UIuhK6Wdd4zr7Hp7WpnYf-c~eaukKCR4Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"From the left: PSJ0030-1525 VST grz colour image; 0.42-arcsec-seeing r-band VST image; 4PSFs+galaxy model with PSF positions overlaid; residuals after model subtraction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177014/sty911fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177014\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&Signature=BpqJwZFH8eQTN5BmqrSBg~lNOXrMW5ZKXPrKSjeoCtKb6xepUxv4x6FiSIm71y9sPYnYRX3~s2uJxmTJy1VkV5~4CCpDIoRALmeONjnmW5wgUhd5UnycoIsFHZsf1jpI6odhrQiaw3cJx4AVK386tNK5~mdSOizbBImJNNlRRJt7gCHOrrG~NTrjTRvq2AbUT2Ur9xSbuyL060~RC7stELC0JxxwHqcuxeVN2N84vQ-Vwx4PLc3UyGfZTuyDgu9BjOcGNDVgzJT98UsVQknO0O5Z8ZRnEpfbMwE5uHAprTNWkbSQEejUVNgWx0TE1pABpfX6GzocM0rTjbFHU4Jx3Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177014&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">From the left: PSJ0030-1525 VST <em>grz</em> colour image; 0.42-arcsec-seeing <em>r</em>-band VST image; 4PSFs+galaxy model with PSF positions overlaid; residuals after model subtraction.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177015 id=\"121177015\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-2>5.1.2 J0127\u22121441</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DECaLS data reveal two faint red objects between the two PSFs that could be responsible for the lensing. These are detected only in the <em>z</em>-band data and each has a magnitude of \u223c24. Comparing to mock lenses from Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) with similar source redshift and image separation, the faintest <em>i</em>-band lens magnitudes are \u223c22. While the multiple component nature of this putative lens complicates the comparison, the faintness and large separation suggest either a binary quasar or high-redshift group lens. Deeper data will help to secure the magnitudes of these objects.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177017 id=\"121177017\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-3>5.1.3 J0139+3526</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While this was a promising candidate given the similar SEDs and residuals consistent with a lensing galaxy, the redshift of the quasars is low (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.65) and the [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission lines are significantly different. There is no discernible redshift difference from the spectra, so this system is likely a quasar merger in which we are seeing the onset of AGN activity. The residuals are probably associated with the quasar host galaxies interacting. A nearby bright star makes this system ideal for adaptive optics follow-up.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177019 id=\"121177019\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-4>5.1.4 J0140-1152</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens has been independently identified in the VST-ATLAS survey by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>), who report a lens redshift of 0.277. It is a highly magnified (\u223c10\u00a0times) double. The elliptical mass model suggests a strong external shear, given the relatively circular light profile of the galaxy.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177021 id=\"121177021\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-5>5.1.5 J0235-2433</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) have independently selected this object as a candidate gravitational lens from the Dark Energy Survey (DES) footprint (The Dark Energy Survey Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). We confirm the PSFs to be quasars at a redshift of 1.44. The DES data displayed in Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) show that the image closest to the lens galaxy is brighter than the other while the opposite is true in the Pan-STARRS data. This change by approximately 1 mag within less than a few years (mean epoch for the Pan-STARRS detection is 56475, and \u223c57350 for DES; Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) is likely attributed to a microlensing event rather than quasar variability. Indeed in the <em>Gaia</em> data, the closest and furthest images have magnitudes of <em>G</em>=18.12 and <em>G</em>=18.85, respectively. Since both images are detected by <em>Gaia</em>, they will have well-sampled light curves over 5\u00a0yr. When released, these light curves will clearly distinguish a microlensing event in one image from quasar variability which would be seen in both images but separated by the time delay.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177023 id=\"121177023\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-6>5.1.6 J0417+3325</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This double has an elliptical lens galaxy (<em>q</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.48) and the SIE lens model is aligned along the same position angle but less elliptical (<em>q</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.65). It was originally detected by Colla et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1970</a>) at 408MHz with a flux of 290\u2009mJy, and subsequently at 5\u2009GHz by Davis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1971</a>) and Altschuler (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>) with detections of 60\u2009mJy and 39\u2009mJy, respectively. It is also detected in NVSS (Condon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) at 1.4\u2009GHz with a flux density of 109\u2009mJy. Archival 8\u2009GHz VLA data show two point sources in the same positions as the optical quasar point sources with a hint of a third source south of image A. There is an extended source 3 arcsec west of the system, lacking any optical detection in Pan-STARRS. The A to B flux ratio at 8\u2009GHz is 1.2, while the <em>g</em>-band ratio \u2013 the magnitudes least affected by the presence of the lens galaxy \u2013 is 2.0, a discrepancy that could be explained by a number of effects including microlensing or extinction. The presence of a radio source is promising for using resolved source structure and radio flux ratios to precisely constrain lens models.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177025 id=\"121177025\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-7>5.1.7 J0630-1201</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system was identified in a novel Pan-STARRS+WISE photometric quasar catalogue as explained in Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Keck NIRC2 data reveal two lensing galaxies and a fifth demagnified image. See Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) for a full mass model.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177027 id=\"121177027\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-8>5.1.8 J0740+2926</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This is an SDSS quasar that was subsequently found to be followed up as part of the SQLS, which also confirms this as a quasar pair at <em>z</em>=0.98 (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177029 id=\"121177029\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-9>5.1.9 J0812+3349</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While we have classified this as a nearly identical quasar (NIQ), there is support for this object being a lens since a faint red object is seen upon subtracting the PSFs. Because of the lack of any imaging data sets other than Pan-STARRS, we cannot confirm this detection since this faint residual is only seen in the <em>i</em> band at <em>i</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a023. The quasars\u2019 proximity could mean lens galaxy light is being fit or appearing due to poor PSF subtraction. Therefore deeper and/or higher-resolution imaging of this system is required.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177031 id=\"121177031\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-10>5.1.10 J0941+0518</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system and J1640+1045 were concurrently discovered by Williams et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Deep CFHT data reveals an Einstein ring of the quasar host galaxy in the <em>u, g</em>, and <em>r</em> bands, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. We calculate the velocity dispersion of our SIE model to be 365\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and compare this to the measured velocity dispersion of the galaxy from an SDSS spectrum of 313\u00b118\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. This discrepancy can be accounted for by a shallower than isothermal density profile of <em>\u03b3</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.8 (see fig.\u00a04 of Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). However, this lens is embedded within a galaxy group and so close companions would suggest a steeper profile (Dobke, King &amp; Fellhauer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Since a quasar emission line from the closer, fainter quasar image is present in the galaxy spectrum, the SDSS velocity dispersion might not be trustworthy. A deeper spectrum and deeper optical imaging of the Einstein ring will help constrain the mass model. We calculate the time delay for this system as B lagging A by \u223c270\u2009d.</p>                        <a id=\"121177033\" scrollto-destination=\"121177033\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">From left to right: J0941+0518 stacked CFHT <em>ugr</em> data, PSF-subtraction, and PSF and galaxy subtraction.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177034 id=\"121177034\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-11>5.1.11 J0949+4208</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This is a radio source in NVSS and FIRST, however FIRST clearly associates it with the lensing galaxy. The lensing galaxy is likely a radio galaxy, however we cannot rule out the fainter optical image being much brighter in the radio. It was targetted for a BOSS spectrum which shows quasar emission lines at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.27 and a galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.507, in agreement with the absorption lines seen in our WHT spectrum.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177036 id=\"121177036\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-12>5.1.12 J1540+4445</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This NIQ is at low redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.61) and shows variation in the emission line profiles between the two components. Furthermore it appears to be associated with a galaxy cluster. Two BOSS spectra of galaxies in the field place them at the same redshift as the NIQ.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177038 id=\"121177038\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-13>5.1.13 J1606\u22122333</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system was identified as a <em>Gaia</em> double. Though the seeing for the WHT spectrum was poor, quasar emission lines are visible across the broad trace. The two-component decomposition is made the same distance as that between the <em>Gaia</em> detections, and a narrow uniform aperture is used for the spectral extraction. An archival, shallow <em>Chandra</em> image shows extended emission at the positions of the two <em>Gaia</em> detections and also near image C, as labelled in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Recent HST imaging (proposal 15320, PI: Treu) clearly resolves four quasar images and a lens galaxy. The mass model suggests a shear of 0.15 and an image position chi-square of \u223c10. The majority of this is attributed to a poorly fitting position of image D. The best-fit models consistently place D 0.02-0.04 arcsec more northern than the measured value. This discrepancy could be explained by an astrometric perturbation from an unresolved galaxy near image D.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177040 id=\"121177040\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-14>5.1.14 J1640+1045</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This double system appears to be a flux-ratio anomaly double with the closest image 1.5 mag brighter than the further image (0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>52 and 1<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>71 from the galaxy, respectively). While this could be explained by microlensing, the fit of an SIE is possible to explain this flux ratio but requires a highly elliptical (<em>q</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.3) mass model, while the light profile is reasonably circular (<em>q</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.9). Therefore if this flux ratio is to be explained by a mass model, it is much more likely to be due to a strong external shear in the same direction as the inferred mass position angle. A singular isothermal sphere + shear model for this system is also a good fit (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\chi^2$|</span> \u223c0.25), with a shear of 0.32 at 122 deg North of East. This position angle is well-aligned with a nearby galaxy less than 4 arcsec from the main lensing galaxy at a position angle of 133 deg North of East. Furthermore SDSS, Pan-STARRS, <em>Gaia</em>, and DECaLS data all show that this lens maintains the measured flux ratio implying this flux ratio is unchanging over 15\u00a0yr. While microlensing events cannot be ruled out, it is more likely that this apparent flux-ratio anomaly is explained by a strong external shear. Since both quasar images are detected by <em>Gaia</em>, their lightcurves will become useful data for breaking the microlensing/shear degeneracy for this system.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177042 id=\"121177042\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-15>5.1.15 J1721+8842</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The 'polar quad' shows strong signs of line-of-sight absorption systems in all four images. The Pan-STARRS imaging data have highly distorted PSFs in some bands, so the mass model is based on flux ratios measured only in the <em>r</em> band. The residuals after subtracting PSFs show flux to the west of image C, perhaps associated with a second lensing galaxy or an arc from the quasar host galaxy. Given its high declination, the position and airmass of this system are essentially unchanged year-round, providing an excellent opportunity to efficiently measure time delays without any seasonal gaps. We note that the mass model is well-fit to the data, with a <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi^2$|</span> of \u223c4.4 (the number of degrees of freedom for the quad models is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$13-9=4$|\u2060</span>). Most of the flux chi-squared contribution comes from image A being too bright. This system was also recovered by Rusu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) in a lens search using the AGN catalogue of Secrest et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177044 id=\"121177044\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-16>5.1.16 J1831+5447</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This is an NVSS radio source with a flux of 23.5\u2009mJy at 1.4\u2009GHz.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177046 id=\"121177046\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1-17>5.1.17 J2032\u22122358</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MgII absorption is seen in just one of the quasar spectra, with the emission lines appearing similar. The MgII absorption system is at <em>z</em>= 1.642, consistent with the source\u2019s systemic redshift based on the C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> and C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> lines and the other quasar\u2019s MgII emission line. This could be a lens with magnesium absorption in the host quasar along the line of sight of just one image. If deeper imaging reveals a lens galaxy or a lensed host galaxy, then this system could be used to constrain the covering fraction of MgII.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121177048 id=\"121177048\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Lens statistics</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To understand the limitations of our selection method, we have compiled a list of 147 previously known lensed quasars against which we can test our selection. While we report 24 new lensed quasars in this paper, our selection criteria also selected 59 previously known lensed quasars, as described in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"121177050\" scrollto-destination=\"121177050\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia</em> selection of lenses with WISE+GMM colour techniques. Numbers shown in brackets are for lenses in the Pan-STARRS footprint. 82 lenses are selected in Pan-STARRS, 23 of which are new lenses presented in this paper and the remaining 59 are known lenses.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Known lensed quasars (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>171 (150)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>4 (4)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> detections<sup><em>a</em></sup> (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>43 (34)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1 <em>Gaia</em> detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>86 (77)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>0<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>38 (35)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Multiples selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Singles selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Known lensed quasars (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>171 (150)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>4 (4)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> detections<sup><em>a</em></sup> (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>43 (34)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1 <em>Gaia</em> detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>86 (77)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>0<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>38 (35)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Multiples selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Singles selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>One of these 43 lenses \u2013 SBS1520+530 \u2013 has one of its two detections due to a nearby star. We keep this in our sample since it would still be selected via this method.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121177050\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia</em> selection of lenses with WISE+GMM colour techniques. Numbers shown in brackets are for lenses in the Pan-STARRS footprint. 82 lenses are selected in Pan-STARRS, 23 of which are new lenses presented in this paper and the remaining 59 are known lenses.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Known lensed quasars (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>171 (150)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>4 (4)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> detections<sup><em>a</em></sup> (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>43 (34)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1 <em>Gaia</em> detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>86 (77)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>0<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>38 (35)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Multiples selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Singles selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><tbody><tr><td>Known lensed quasars (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>171 (150)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>4 (4)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2 <em>Gaia</em> detections<sup><em>a</em></sup> (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>43 (34)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1 <em>Gaia</em> detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>86 (77)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>0<em>Gaia</em>detections (in PS)\u00a0</td><td>38 (35)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Multiples selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Singles selected by WISE or GMM in PS\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>One of these 43 lenses \u2013 SBS1520+530 \u2013 has one of its two detections due to a nearby star. We keep this in our sample since it would still be selected via this method.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121177050\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177051 id=\"121177051\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-1>5.2.1 Recovering known lenses</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Of the 171 known lenses (including our sample), 4 lenses have 3 <em>Gaia</em> detections, 43 have 2 detections, 86 have 1 detection, and 38 have no detections. Of the 38 with no <em>Gaia</em> detections, only 2 have bright enough images that should be detectable by <em>Gaia</em> \u2013 J0941+0518 and WFI2026-4536 \u2013 with the rest being optically faint mainly due to radio selection.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Applying our selection criteria (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>), we recover 82 lenses (37 <em>Gaia</em> multiples and 45 <em>Gaia</em> singles). 23 of these lenses are quadruply imaged (quad fraction of 28<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{ per cent}$|\u2060</span>), while of all known lenses the quad fraction is 43/171 (25<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{ per cent}$|\u2060</span>). The lenses that we fail to select fall into three categories: separation\u00a0&gt;\u00a04 arcsec, separation \u223c1 arcsec, or high flux ratio doubles. We do not recover the very rare large-separation lenses because of our 4 arcsec <em>Gaia</em> multiple separation cut. The small-separation lenses are missed because of lack of multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections (see Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and in the case of just one <em>Gaia</em> detection, the system is not extended enough and does not pass our morphological classifier. This latter failure also explains the high flux ratio doubles being missed, since the majority of the flux is in one PSF.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121177054 id=\"121177054\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-2>5.2.2 Known versus simulated lenses</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our search techniques failed to recover 33 known lenses with <em>Gaia</em> detections. We understand this as the extremes of small- and high-separation images and high flux-ratio doubles. We can verify this and infer which lenses our search is missing by comparing the selected lenses to a simulated sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In particular, we compare to the Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) (OM10 hereafter) simulations which have readily listed image configurations, lensing galaxy parameters, source parameters etc., for 15\u00a0658 mock systems. We limit the entire OM10 sample to those lenses we would expect to be able to find with images brighter than the <em>Gaia</em> threshold. For this criterion we use all lenses that have the faintest image (or second faintest for quads) brighter than <em>i</em> = 21, leaving a catalogue of 2560 mock lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> show histograms of source redshifts and separations, respectively, for our 23 <em>Gaia</em> lens sample, the 82 <em>Gaia</em>-selected known lenses and the reduced OM10 sample. The first plot demonstrates the lack of known lenses at redshifts above <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.2. Two reasons for this are (i) SQLS targetted lenses below this redshift for their statistical sample and (ii) the <em>u</em>-band dropout for quasars above <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.7 makes them more difficult to classify, and at higher redshifts WISE colours tend to become bluer for quasars (as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). The second plot shows that small-separation lenses are being missed. This is naturally expected since these are the hardest to identify in imaging data and to target for follow-up spectroscopy.</p>                        <a id=\"121177058\" scrollto-destination=\"121177058\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465628&amp;Signature=StF8jZ8fvcxs~7NTNCmTUMjiZBYVoEWZQ0lP84IN-mxuTK6haZOIoWynxMQBnDb4Z-~Nk-JtgbUob~e6-5kEETKg11hTQNOWGALeRUV8vL7yxKMoyrDItl-ZlO1RmW5Ep3QpDcZ2FvptwXTbVvBSzpRma7ufIgZG0-9Dyi-bH564Cy~3fD3teyDtif6wn3PzZIEsu0gXwuPvNTvJcEeaHloaDrMUs43Xh454htl1AyfuGubytLapmHRBl5t7CBbs~mbXLco6Dvy5pOvPUzBOKbFSeP8cdJrP2uZDael7RXGjNc8k2XRoNMFwTtq-rU7x0BoYQoTpZo-phX32b0AXbw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"W1 against W1\u2212W2 for all known lenses with at least one Gaia detection and robust WISE photometry, coloured by source redshift. <em>Gaia</em> sample, all <em>Gaia</em> -selected lenses, and OM10 mock lenses.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"121177060\" scrollto-destination=\"121177060\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&amp;Signature=GsrLLXxORPUER7Nm-sj8thvtpaCM49TNzAfnxSt6jkioAmxgrHSS8sY332hp~a6czMYMH2Jhfds1LnySugaMzvP3241tMNG00If9e1~DVvg4Dn35kYiaCStubtb-oj-C5Z9XZ6z3dK6XwYWqSVX5HVr94Ahzzz5BSkW3xpsiYgNfQkNQeMJPXcT~KSFbCGjm0swJkcnSChaiAfSNDTayvQiquaUx6cRCCBMtN72o6uneW4wbTYwb4FTNrpdsBK6YbN6wKBhx3WBTNrLZ5iM23mUIJapJZ84Zmh5GBhUbC1kmkWVB-cLy2c0OuBZDiLUc4gpVcjrdX21DMe1RfVNDLQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Image separation distributions for our Gaia sample, all Gaia-selected lenses, and OM10 mock lenses. OM10 used a lower limit of 0${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$5 for the image separation of their mocks and 4 arcsec as an upper limit.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177060/sty911fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177060\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&Signature=Y0Q8StREHhE-wLgi5ny3x5Xwjvdr9ezwrPUFyOkKVfQpnoehwzmArOv~-uWXm0OZqAe406tY3ghpXiXHI2NK7wvvyynwzO1fsWkmLi9Zbg5KstKrO9tOvUCUMLp62~qo3cLWYa0c9En9PecS4I8HSEUXtz6mG7BsDUEq~pje8bVg2~o12tB4WAvGPrY9Uxww-KrYz-Y0xcavIseiHZxD9GcwdDf2~dF0xFw2och2PyyUYwTI4v1P62Mq68TsdxoiGcQ-gTBNq0MLbjXRJjfcQ5HO4j2kerKisMFMvKD2pnFanqkNCGj46n2ufSlpS7iG09tWuD5gfOlT-I58~x9xBQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177060&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image separation distributions for our <em>Gaia</em> sample, all <em>Gaia</em>-selected lenses, and OM10 mock lenses. OM10 used a lower limit of 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>5 for the image separation of their mocks and 4 arcsec as an upper limit.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&amp;Signature=GsrLLXxORPUER7Nm-sj8thvtpaCM49TNzAfnxSt6jkioAmxgrHSS8sY332hp~a6czMYMH2Jhfds1LnySugaMzvP3241tMNG00If9e1~DVvg4Dn35kYiaCStubtb-oj-C5Z9XZ6z3dK6XwYWqSVX5HVr94Ahzzz5BSkW3xpsiYgNfQkNQeMJPXcT~KSFbCGjm0swJkcnSChaiAfSNDTayvQiquaUx6cRCCBMtN72o6uneW4wbTYwb4FTNrpdsBK6YbN6wKBhx3WBTNrLZ5iM23mUIJapJZ84Zmh5GBhUbC1kmkWVB-cLy2c0OuBZDiLUc4gpVcjrdX21DMe1RfVNDLQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Image separation distributions for our Gaia sample, all Gaia-selected lenses, and OM10 mock lenses. OM10 used a lower limit of 0${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$5 for the image separation of their mocks and 4 arcsec as an upper limit.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177060/sty911fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177060\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&Signature=Y0Q8StREHhE-wLgi5ny3x5Xwjvdr9ezwrPUFyOkKVfQpnoehwzmArOv~-uWXm0OZqAe406tY3ghpXiXHI2NK7wvvyynwzO1fsWkmLi9Zbg5KstKrO9tOvUCUMLp62~qo3cLWYa0c9En9PecS4I8HSEUXtz6mG7BsDUEq~pje8bVg2~o12tB4WAvGPrY9Uxww-KrYz-Y0xcavIseiHZxD9GcwdDf2~dF0xFw2och2PyyUYwTI4v1P62Mq68TsdxoiGcQ-gTBNq0MLbjXRJjfcQ5HO4j2kerKisMFMvKD2pnFanqkNCGj46n2ufSlpS7iG09tWuD5gfOlT-I58~x9xBQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177060&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image separation distributions for our <em>Gaia</em> sample, all <em>Gaia</em>-selected lenses, and OM10 mock lenses. OM10 used a lower limit of 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>5 for the image separation of their mocks and 4 arcsec as an upper limit.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that the quad fraction of the mocks is 18<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{ per cent}$|\u2060</span>, compared to 25<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{ per cent}$|</span> for all known lenses, demonstrating current and previous search biases towards quads \u2013 they are more identifiable once visually inspected and more likely to be caught by search algorithms (e.g. higher likelihood of multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> shows the fainter image magnitude against galaxy magnitude in the <em>i</em> band for our <em>Gaia</em> lens sample. Overlaid are the same values for the entire OM10 mock catalogue. Naturally we are still discovering the brightest lenses on the sky, but we note that there should be many more lenses with bright images with faint galaxies, and faint images with bright galaxies (the top left and the bottom right, respectively). The NIQs identified in this paper can make up the former of these two classes of lens, but require deeper imaging to reveal the lens galaxy. The latter will be missed by searches requiring quasar colour selection. These lenses could be discovered by starting from photometric galaxies and requiring multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections, as Lucey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) have successfully applied to the Pan-STARRS data set.</p>                        <a id=\"121177063\" scrollto-destination=\"121177063\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&amp;Signature=IDlOe5V3y5eRFAPEMm5XKuEvopKSHtVZyUEYgxZoUl90LFHHHQ6coSBo-8K4h8CWAHGyx8TWisziJ-O35xKXm6~fJDO~2fRO440FWpp6OB5q4Nzd3g0TSj-bCIsxAXMUcUJgR5Z38aASMO999GvRQ0Y1Cj3-a0h6wRSV4miur4q8bJ6XDv0DrfP0ki~ePGEZF7DwQZu0OZrBrgkF8u1YjLqevC2CV5d3ibh9VQ9a7HHL-SgHz4QXZrn9t4XFB75GNpDkoRj3KqLa8Q~~tKc7GPJBol0Ol5zu-wNN-hD8XU~~bxxtJBVOM078sZm-msrdOhm-al7P2lniRLcmhC-2Cw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fainter image (second faintest for quads) magnitudes against lensing galaxy magnitudes in the i band. Yellow dots are from our modelled sample and blue is the entire OM10 simulations (no brightness limit).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177063/sty911fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177063\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&Signature=SI2fH8AJmkJ9Z2~XsclHxfbbRjza1RP3PqJMc111RvnA0s6jydESIs7MkgXDdxHLzDRPRADSTybs9M8JtHXJFGNQrcHi3CYKXox5OpalIQTi914-6b462GdXR-TJLraGde0nr1CnOcVXm2REDzkWAST0GwYuMzWLVnJ4Yhwd7TXwituVlrdgP5umbhDwtNQtdo4j4K~SAu9dAdoe7BySMku4xyAj2xniQFHA0kv4LRWvOR49TNcZhvSUqDQkAtftapfWwvKb3jk3K7OSVhmghb1twvhFNTfgykNr5Zn0XwVvSr3RpnETmTEfbQrvQGLNOTXa6C5RtDKVdEx4jkb~hA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177063&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fainter image (second faintest for quads) magnitudes against lensing galaxy magnitudes in the <em>i</em> band. Yellow dots are from our modelled sample and blue is the entire OM10 simulations (no brightness limit).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/m_sty911fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&amp;Signature=IDlOe5V3y5eRFAPEMm5XKuEvopKSHtVZyUEYgxZoUl90LFHHHQ6coSBo-8K4h8CWAHGyx8TWisziJ-O35xKXm6~fJDO~2fRO440FWpp6OB5q4Nzd3g0TSj-bCIsxAXMUcUJgR5Z38aASMO999GvRQ0Y1Cj3-a0h6wRSV4miur4q8bJ6XDv0DrfP0ki~ePGEZF7DwQZu0OZrBrgkF8u1YjLqevC2CV5d3ibh9VQ9a7HHL-SgHz4QXZrn9t4XFB75GNpDkoRj3KqLa8Q~~tKc7GPJBol0Ol5zu-wNN-hD8XU~~bxxtJBVOM078sZm-msrdOhm-al7P2lniRLcmhC-2Cw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fainter image (second faintest for quads) magnitudes against lensing galaxy magnitudes in the i band. Yellow dots are from our modelled sample and blue is the entire OM10 simulations (no brightness limit).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121177063/sty911fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121177063\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty911/2/sty911fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465629&Signature=SI2fH8AJmkJ9Z2~XsclHxfbbRjza1RP3PqJMc111RvnA0s6jydESIs7MkgXDdxHLzDRPRADSTybs9M8JtHXJFGNQrcHi3CYKXox5OpalIQTi914-6b462GdXR-TJLraGde0nr1CnOcVXm2REDzkWAST0GwYuMzWLVnJ4Yhwd7TXwituVlrdgP5umbhDwtNQtdo4j4K~SAu9dAdoe7BySMku4xyAj2xniQFHA0kv4LRWvOR49TNcZhvSUqDQkAtftapfWwvKb3jk3K7OSVhmghb1twvhFNTfgykNr5Zn0XwVvSr3RpnETmTEfbQrvQGLNOTXa6C5RtDKVdEx4jkb~hA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121177063&ar=4970775&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty911fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fainter image (second faintest for quads) magnitudes against lensing galaxy magnitudes in the <em>i</em> band. Yellow dots are from our modelled sample and blue is the entire OM10 simulations (no brightness limit).</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121177064 id=\"121177064\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented the discovery of 24 gravitationally lensed quasars; 13 are discovered by having multiple <em>Gaia</em> components, 10 as <em>Gaia</em> detections near morphological galaxies, and 1 from an emission line identification in an SDSS galaxy spectrum. All of these systems have well-resolved images in ground-based imaging and are bright, lending themselves to monitoring and subsequent time delay cosmography studies (Treu &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Our sample includes four quadruply imaged lenses and one double lens which shows a blue Einstein ring in deep CFHT data. One quad, J0030-1525, requires high-resolution imaging to verify our understanding that one image is highly demagnified, by a factor of \u223c14. Four of our lenses \u2013 J0140-1152, J0146-1133, J0235-2433, and J0259-2338 \u2013 have been independently identified using a complementary <em>Gaia</em> and WISE selection by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) and Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparing our sample of lensed quasars to simulations, we show that we are not sensitive to arcsecond-separation lenses and those at redshifts beyond the <em>u</em>-band dropout. This is due to colour selection and the bias from visually inspecting a large number of candidates. This biases our sample towards systems with bright lensing galaxies and quads, and away from small-separation lenses and bright doubles that are often confused for stars. The second <em>Gaia</em> data release on 2018 April 25 will not only help increase the completeness of lens searches through detection of more lensed quasar images and colour information from the blue and red photometers, but also drastically reduce the number of candidates that must be inspected. Further data release, including proper motion information, will further remove contaminants.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) predict several thousand lensed quasars to be detectable using LSST (Large Synoptic Survey Telescope), however to confirm such large numbers of lenses to become useful astrophysical and cosmological tools, we must ensure we select lenses efficiently and in a complete manner. We have demonstrated that combining <em>Gaia</em>, WISE, SDSS, and Pan-STARRS data with pixel-based modelling can efficiently select new lenses \u2013 a 57<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{ per cent}$|</span> success rate (including binaries).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121177068 id=\"121177068\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">CAL and RGM would like to thank the STFC, and MWA acknowledges support from the STFC in the form of an Ernest Rutherford Fellowship. This work has made use of data from the European Space Agency (ESA) mission <em>Gaia</em> (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia</a>), processed by the <em>Gaia</em> Data Processing and Analysis Consortium (DPAC, <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/gaia/dpac/consortium\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/gaia/dpac/consortium</a>). Funding for the DPAC has been provided by national institutions, in particular the institutions participating in the <em>Gaia</em> Multilateral Agreement. The Pan-STARRS1 Surveys (PS1) and the PS1 public science archive have been made possible through contributions by the Institute for Astronomy, the University of Hawaii, the Pan-STARRS Project Office, the Max-Planck Society and its participating institutes, the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, Heidelberg, and the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics, Garching, The Johns Hopkins University, Durham University, the University of Edinburgh, the Queen\u2019s University Belfast, the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, the Las Cumbres Observatory Global Telescope Network Incorporated, the National Central University of Taiwan, the Space Telescope Science Institute, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration under Grant No. NNX08AR22G issued through the Planetary Science Division of the NASA Science Mission Directorate, the National Science Foundation Grant No. AST-1238877, the University of Maryland, Eotvos Lorand University (ELTE), the Los Alamos National Laboratory, and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation. This publication makes use of data products from the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer, which is a joint project of the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory/California Institute of Technology, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121177070 id=\"121177070\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abbott</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T. "https://academic.oup.com/view-large/121176998", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": ">For full access to this pdf, sign in to an existing account, or purchase an annual subscription."}}}, "Paper Overview": {"authors": ["Lemon, Cameron A.", "Auger, Matthew W.", "McMahon, Richard G.", "Ostrovski, Fernanda"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "abstract": "We report the discovery, spectroscopic confirmation, and preliminary characterization of 24 gravitationally lensed quasars identified using Gaia observations. Candidates were selected in the Pan-STARRS footprint with quasar-like WISE colours or as photometric quasars from Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), requiring either multiple detections in Gaia or a single Gaia detection near a morphological galaxy. The Pan-STARRS grizY images were modelled for the most promising candidates and 60 candidate systems were followed up with the William Herschel Telescope. 13 of the lenses were discovered as Gaia multiples and 10 as single Gaia detections near galaxies. We also discover 1 lens identified through a quasar emission line in an SDSS galaxy spectrum. The lenses have median image separation 2.13 arcsec and the source redshifts range from 1.06 to 3.36. 4 systems are quadruply imaged and 20 are doubly imaged. Deep CFHT data reveal an Einstein ring in one double system. We also report 12 quasar pairs, 10 of which have components at the same redshift and require further follow-up to rule out the lensing hypothesis. We compare the properties of these lenses and other known lenses recovered by our search method to a complete sample of simulated lenses to show the lenses we are missing are mainly those with small separations and higher source redshifts. The initial Gaia data release only catalogues all images of \u223c30 per cent of known bright lensed quasars, however the improved completeness of Gaia data release 2 will help find all bright lensed quasars on the sky.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/sty911", "start_page": "5060", "number": "4", "publication_year": "2018/10/1", "end_page": "5074", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1803.07601", "author_address": ["AA(Institute of Astronomy, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK; Kavli Institute for Cosmology, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK), AB(Institute of Astronomy, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK), AC(Institute of Astronomy, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK; Kavli Institute for Cosmology, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK), AD(Institute of Astronomy, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK; Kavli Institute for Cosmology, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK)"], "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: observational", "quasars: general", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018MNRAS.479.5060L", "volume": "479", "Title": "Gravitationally lensed quasars in Gaia - II. Discovery of 24 lensed quasars", "issn": "0035-8711"}}
